Other Options

Destiny Bond allows Drifblim to sacrifice itself to eliminate checks such as Skuntank and Rhydon in the event they stop its sweep, but it is difficult to justify over any of Drifblim's other moves.

Checks and Counters

Special Walls: Without Substitute or multiple boosts, special walls such as Clefairy and Stunfisk easily tank Shadow Ball and cripple Drifblim with status. Drifblim particularly struggles with bulky Normal-types such as Miltank, as they can easily take a boosted Thunderbolt and Toxic it in return, while Substitute sets are completely unable to damage them.

Dark-types: Physical Dark-types that can get past Strength Sap, such as Silvally-Dark, Shiftry, and Morpeko, can easily overwhelm Drifblim. Specially offensive Dark-types, such as Skuntank and Thievul, have no trouble breaking through Drifblim.

Strong Wallbreakers: Wallbreakers that can hit Drifblim super effectively such as Manectric and Rhydon easily break through Drifblim even after a boost. However, these Pokemon must be kept healthy to check Drifblim.

Setup Sweepers: Setup sweepers that can boost their Special Defense, such as Alcremie, can easily turn Drifblim into setup fodder. Other setup sweepers, such as Ninetales and Rapidash, can't reliably defeat Drifblim, but can usually trade with it.

sets.name: Terrain Sweeper
sets.description:
Drifblim's access to Unburden and Calm Mind makes it an effective Electric Terrain sweeper when equipped with an Electric Seed. Strength Sap lets Drifblim use physical attackers such as Thwackey and Gurdurr as setup fodder and provides it with reliable recovery. Thunderbolt is used to hit Pokemon that resist or are immune to Ghost, such as Kangaskhan and Alolan Persian, neutrally, while Substitute can be used to avoid status from walls such as Tangela and Pyukumuku and to ease Drifblim's setup. However, not using Thunderbolt leads to Drifblim being completely walled by Normal-types. This Speed investment allows Drifblim to outspeed Choice Scarf Manectric after Unburden. Electric Seed allows Drifblim to easily trigger Unburden when Electric Terrain is up, and its Defense boost pairs well with Calm Mind and mitigates Drifblim's weakness to Knock Off.

Pincurchin is mandatory as a teammate due to Drifblim needing Electric Terrain to trigger Unburden. Due to special walls often being able to take Drifblim's boosted attacks and retaliate with status, Drifblim prefers being paired with Pokemon that share checks with it, such as special sweepers like Thievul and Swoobat and wallbreakers like Manectric and Raichu, to break through specially bulky Pokemon. In particular, Rising Voltage from the aforementioned wallbreakers is invaluable for facilitating a Drifblim sweep, as they can overpower checks such as Miltank and Spiritomb, while Drifblim can clean up any remaining threats. Pokemon that can force out Dark- and Normal-types such as Sawk and Alolan Persian are also appreciated teammates. Finally, pivots such as Uxie make good partners, as they can create setup opportunities for Drifblim by giving it a free switch into a favorable matchup.

Skuntank.comments:
Other Options

Life Orb provides additional damage output, but the recoil damage limits Skuntank's longevity and makes it prone to entry hazards. Defog and Heavy-Duty Boots turn Skuntank into an offensive entry hazard remover, but this makes it inconsistent in its stallbreaking role.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine are able to take a boosted hit from Skuntank and OHKO it back with their STAB moves.

Faster Offensive Threats: Skuntank's mediocre Speed leaves it susceptible to faster attackers such as Rapidash, Kangskhan, and Froslass. Special wallbreakers and pivots like Rotom and Basculin can also threaten to revenge kill Skuntank, preventing it from consistently performing its role. However, physical attackers should be wary of residual damage from Aftermath.

Special Walls: Although they do not appreciate Taunt, Corrosive Gas, and being poisoned by Sludge Bomb, special walls such as Articuno and Type: Null are able to take boosted hits from Skuntank and pivot with U-turn, safely bringing in revenge killers to threaten it. Galarian Stunfisk is able to wear down Skuntank if it lacks Fire Blast.

sets.name: Stallbreaker
sets.description:
Skuntank is a great stallbreaker in ZU; its Poison / Dark typing gives it various opportunities to set up against foes such as Uxie and Tangela. While initially weak, Skuntank can pummel passive walls like Clefairy and Cofagrigus with Nasty Plot and its STAB coverage. Taunt can be used to prevent foes like Miltank and Pyukumuku from recovering HP. Alternatively, Corrosive Gas cripples common checks like Rhydon, Articuno, and Stunfisk.

Skuntank fits best on offense and balance teams that appreciate its Toxic and Psychic immunities, stallbreaking, and ability to pressure Ghost-, Psychic-, and Fairy-types like Cofagrigus, Uxie, and Clefairy. Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine are able to heavily pressure Skuntank; checks to them such as Basculin and Cramorant are appreciated. The aforementioned Water-types can also lure in Grass-types like Thwackey and Tangela for Skuntank to take advantage of. Partners like Sawk and Swords Dance Silvally formes benefit from Skuntank weakening foes such as Tangela, Qwilfish, and Alcremie to clean late-game.

Spiritomb.comments:
Other Options

Spiritomb can run a physical wallbreaker set with Choice Band thanks to powerful moves in Poltergeist and Sucker Punch. Choice Band also pairs well with Trick, as it lets Spiritomb cripple the few Pokemon that can safely switch into Poltergeist such as Miltank and Tangela. However, Spiritomb is too slow to be a real offensive threat and being Choice-locked into Sucker Punch makes it very exploitable.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Shiftry, Skuntank, and Silvally-Dark resist Spiritomb's Dark Pulse and use it as setup fodder or, in Alolan Persian's case, beat it with the combination of Taunt + Toxic.

Wallbreakers: With no way of boosting its average physical bulk and Rest as its only form of recovery, Spiritomb gets overpowered by strong physical wallbreakers such as Flapple, Basculin, and Silvally formes. Spiritomb's special bulk is also lackluster before setting up a Calm Mind, and it can be forced out by special wallbreakers like Choice Specs Rotom and Basculin.

Alcremie: Alcremie is able to use Spiritomb as setup fodder for its Calm Mind sets and defeat it with Dazzling Gleam, while it is unable to do much in return. It should, however, be noted that mono-attacking variants of Alcremie running Stored Power get PP stalled by Spiritomb.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Spiritomb is a fearsome defensive Calm Mind sweeper that is able to find setup opportunities against some threats like Sawk locked into Close Combat, Swoobat, and Cofagrigus. Dark Pulse is the preferred STAB move, as, unlike Shadow Ball, it has no immunities. Rest is Spiritomb's most reliable recovery move and lets it get rid of status. Sleep Talk prevents Spritomb from being completely passive during Rest. Pressure lets Spiritomb PP stall defensive walls like Throh and Clefairy.

Spiritomb fits best on stall teams where its initial passivity isn't as crippling, and its unique defensive utility and PP stalling capabilities are appreciated. On these teams, Spiritomb's teammates whittle down and remove its counters over the course of a match, so it can be used as a late-game wincon. Physical walls like Pyukumuku, Tangela, and Altaria handle powerful wallbreakers such as Basculin and Silvally formes. Special walls like Clefairy and Articuno are necessary to handle special wallbreakers such as Ninetales and Basculin, which can force out an unboosted Spiritomb. Some of them even provide Heal Bell support to wake up Spiritomb after it uses Rest. Checks to Dark-types like Alcremie, Mawile, and Throh are appreciated for their ability to take on foes such as Skuntank and Shiftry, which use Spiritomb as setup fodder. Checks to Alcremie such as Pyukumuku and Haze Articuno are also necessary, as it is a major threat to stall teams and can freely come in on Spiritomb.

Leafeon.comments:
Other Options

Weather Ball targets physically defensive Grass-types like Tangela, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S, but they already do not appreciate taking a Knock Off or Double-Edge. Synthesis provides Leafeon with sun-boosted recovery and counteracts the residual damage from Life Orb.

Checks and Counters

Grass-resistant Pokemon: Pokemon such as Altaria, Gourgeist-XL, and Tangela resist Solar Blade and are able to pressure Leafeon with status. However, they dislike being crippled by Knock Off and weakened by Double-Edge.

Poison-types: Although they do not appreciate Knock Off or Double-Edge, Poison-types such as Silvally-Poison and Skuntank are able to take unboosted hits from Leafeon and retaliate with their STAB moves.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash threaten Leafeon, although they must be wary of Knock Off and Double-Edge.

Residual Damage and Priority: Recoil from Life Orb and Double-Edge, as well as residual damage from entry hazards, limits Leafeon's survivability and makes it susceptible to being revenge killed by foes such as Kangaskhan and Piloswine.

sets.name: Sun Sweeper
sets.description:
Leafeon finds a niche on sun teams as a physical sweeper, utilizing its bulk to set up with Swords Dance and threaten foes with a Life Orb-boosted Solar Blade. Leaf Blade is a notable alternative over Solar Blade that, despite its lower damage output, provides a reliable STAB attack when sun is not up. Knock Off allows Leafeon to weaken Grass-resistant foes such as Ninetales, Tangela, and Silvally-Poison. Double-Edge gives Leafeon coverage against problematic foes like Skuntank, Altaria, and the aforementioned Ninetales and Silvally-Poison.

Sun setters such as Uxie, Liepard, and Exeggutor are mandatory, as they enable Leafeon to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame and let it utilize Solar Blade. Leafeon can form an attacking core with other sun sweepers such as Shiftry and Ivysaur, with all weakening each other's shared checks in Pokemon such as Skuntank. Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash can also take advantage of sun to boost their STAB moves and threaten foes such as Tangela and Thwackey. Ground-types such as Piloswine and Rhydon can take advantage of Poison- and Fire-types that Leafeon invites in and use that opportunity to fire off a strong hit or set Stealth Rock; in return, they appreciate Leafeon threatening opposing Water-types like Poliwrath and Basculin.

Rotom.comments:
Other Options

Toxic can be used over Will-O-Wisp to better cripple defensive walls like Miltank and Coalossal at the expense of not punishing physical attackers as hard. Discharge is an alternative to Thunderbolt on sets with Hex. Rotom can forgo Special Attack investment and run a more bulky set with maximum HP investment to better check physical Ground- and Fighting-types like Piloswine and Sawk.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Silvally-Dark and Alolan Persian are faster than non-Choice Scarf Rotom and can revenge kill it easily. Skuntank can use Rotom as setup fodder if it has locked itself into Shadow Ball. Shiftry and Morpeko resist Rotom's STAB attacks but must be wary of switching into Will-O-Wisp or being pivoted upon, as they are quite frail.

Electric-immune Pokemon: Rhydon, Piloswine, Stunfisk, and Manectric can safely switch into Rotom's Electric-type attacks, especially if it has a Choice item. However, Rhydon and Piloswine dislike Will-O-Wisp and Trick, and all of the aforementioned Pokemon do not enjoy switching into Choice Specs Shadow Ball.

Specially Bulky Pokemon: Despite Rotom having a decent Special Attack stat, it struggles to break past Pokemon with solid special bulk, as they can take a hit and retaliate. Throh can threaten Rotom immediately with Knock Off. Specially defensive walls such as Clefairy, Appletun, and Malamar are great long-term checks, as they have reliable recovery; Clefairy can also pivot into a revenge killer, while the latter two threaten Rotom immediately.

Faster Threats: Non-Choice Scarf Rotom is very susceptible to being revenge killed by Choice Scarf users such as Sawk and Basculin. Faster Pokemon such as Rapidash, Froslass, and Gourgeist-S threaten Rotom. Pokemon with priority moves such as Thwackey and Kangaskhan can also threaten to revenge kill Rotom after some prior chip damage.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf improves Rotom's revenge killing capabilities at the cost of some wallbreaking power; it outpaces foes like Froslass, Silvally-Poison, and Choice Scarf Sawk. Volt Switch can be used to pick off weakened foes while also keeping momentum against potential switch-ins. Trick can be used once there isn't a need for Rotom's revenge killing purposes and punishes passive walls like Galarian Stunfisk and Articuno. Thunderbolt makes for a great cleaning move, as it is a stronger Electric-type STAB move that doesn't force Rotom out. Alternatively, Will-O-Wisp cripples opposing targets, namely physical Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Galarian Stunfisk, while Defog is useful on teams that cannot fit entry hazard removal elsewhere.

Rotom enjoys the luxury of being able to use Volt Switch as often as possible, so having a entry hazard remover such as Articuno, Altaria, or Coalossal is a good idea. Pairing Rotom with Pokemon that can deal with Ground-types like Poliwrath and Gourgeist-S is also recommended to achieve this goal. Rotom also benefits greatly from entry hazard support, as it wants to use Volt Switch often to force out common Pokemon like Qwilfish and Articuno and wear down common switch-ins such as Throh and Audino. Good examples of entry hazard setters include Miltank, Qwilfish, and Rhydon. Physically offensive threats such as Sawk, Rapidash, and Silvally-Dark benefit from Rotom's ability to bring them in safely after forcing out their checks. Rotom is great on VoltTurn cores and works well with other pivots such as Articuno, Silvally formes, and Thwackey.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
With great status moves and Volt Switch, Rotom is a great offensive pivot that offers solid utility. Defog is great on teams that need entry hazard control, while Pain Split provides Rotom with a form of recovery. Will-O-Wisp cripples physical attackers and Ground-types such as Rhydon, Kangaskhan, Thwackey, and Piloswine, and it also boosts the power of Hex. Colbur Berry prevents Rotom from being KOed by Sawk's Knock Off, which gives Rotom a chance to cripple it with a burn, while Heavy-Duty Boots allows Rotom to avoid taking Stealth Rock damage when pivoting. Sitrus Berry can be used for more general increased longevity and is preferred over Leftovers due to the constant pivoting.

Rotom is best used on bulky offense and balance teams that benefit from its ability to disrupt opposing teams and offer support with Defog. Pokemon such as Kangaskhan, Thwackey, and Sawk that appreciate Rotom's ability to bring them in safely; and in return, they can make up for Rotom's lack of immediate power, as it is reliant on spreading burns in order to maximize its power. Offensive threats such as Rapidash, Ninetales, and Skuntank appreciate Rotom's ability to lure in Ground-types and cripple them with burns. Rapidash and Ninetales also benefit from Defog and Rotom forcing out Water-types like Poliwrath and Cramorant. Skuntank helps Rotom by checking faster Ghost-types such as Gourgeist-S and Choice Scarf Rotom and Dark-types like Shiftry and Thievul. Other status inducers like Thunder Wave Qwilfish and Toxic Rapidash pair well with Hex.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Rotom is one of the most threatening special attackers in ZU due to the lack of Pokemon that resist its STAB combination. Choice Specs further facilitates Rotom's wallbreaking power by letting it nab 2HKOs on most walls, while its solid Speed allows it to revenge kill a weakened Skuntank or Rotom-S. Volt Switch lets Rotom gain momentum on Water- and Flying-types and get out of bad matchups against threats such as Throh and Appletun. Trick can be used not only to immediately cripple the aforementioned specially defensive walls but also to punish Ground-types that may attempt to block its Volt Switch attempts, such as Stunfisk and Piloswine.

Rotom is susceptible to being revenge killed by faster Dark-types like Alolan Persian and Silvally-Dark if it is locked into Shadow Ball; therefore, it is imperative that you pair Rotom with Fighting- or Fairy-types such as Sawk, Gurdurr, Alcremie, and Clefairy. The aforementioned Fighting-types also benefit from Rotom's ability to break past physical walls such as Tangela and Uxie and can deal with Normal-types like Kangaskhan and Miltank so Rotom can use Shadow Ball more freely. Pivots such as Thwackey and Silvally formes make for great partners, as they can bring Rotom in safely and form a solid VoltTurn core. Tangela and Appletun can switch into Ground-types like Stunfisk and Rhydon should Rotom lock into an Electric-type move.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Nasty Plot Rotom is a great wallbreaker on offensive teams. With a single boost, Rotom OHKOes physical walls such as Tangela and Poliwrath and has a chance to 2HKO specially defensive walls such as Clefairy and Articuno. Substitute lets Rotom block status attempts from Altaria and Miltank and set up on them freely.

Thwackey can lure in Flying-types and bring in Rotom safely so it can freely set up with Nasty Plot. In return, Rotom can break past physical walls such as Tangela, Poliwrath, and Altaria, which Thwackey struggles with. Late-game cleaners such Alcremie benefit greatly from Rotom's ability to weaken special walls such as Galarian Stunfisk and Articuno. Teleport Clefairy is a great defensive pivot that can absorb Dark-type attacks from revenge killers like Silvally-Dark and Choice Scarf Sawk. Rotom also appreciates having Knock Off users like Shiftry and Alolan Persian to weaken special walls such as Throh and Clefairy.

Rotom-Fan.comments:
Other Options

Thunder Wave and Toxic are valid replacements for Will-O-Wisp, but the former is punished by switching into Ground-types, which already don’t fear Rotom-S's other moves, and the latter allows switch-ins such as Galarian Stunfisk to come in more easily. Discharge can used as Rotom-S's Electric-type STAB move to paralyze offensive switch-ins but leaves it worse off versus bulkier Pokemon. Rotom-S can be a team's Choice Scarf user, but its weakness to Stealth Rock, vulnerability to common priority moves such as Ice Shard, and direct competition with Rotom make it suboptimal for that role.

Checks and Counters

Bulky Ground-types: Ground-types such as Piloswine, Galarian Stunfisk, and Rhydon block Rotom-S's Volt Switch and Thunderbolt and take little from Air Slash. All of them, however, don’t appreciate taking a Will-O-Wisp on the switch.

Revenge Killers: Faster attackers with moves to hit Rotom-S hard such as Froslass and Silvally formes are able to pressure it out with ease.

Toxic: Taking Toxic from users such as Altaria, Alolan Persian, and Miltank cripples Rotom-S due to its unreliable recovery.

Knock Off: Knock Off users like Sawk, Thwackey, and Gurdurr are difficult for Rotom-S to consistently switch into. Entry hazard setters with access to Knock Off such as Uxie and Clefairy also make it hard for Rotom-S to consistently remove entry hazards throughout a game.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Rotom-S is one of the premier entry hazard removers in the metagame due to its ability to pivot with Volt Switch and excellent defensive typing that lets it wall and threaten common Pokemon such as Qwilfish and Sawk. Will-O-Wisp allows Rotom-S to cripple physical attackers such as Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Rhydon on the switch, while Pain Split gives greater but unreliable longevity. 252 Speed EVs let Rotom-S outspeed relevant Pokemon such as Cramorant, Qwilfish, and Choice Band Sawk. Investing in Special Attack over HP to pressure common walls like Altaria, Cofagrigus, and Piloswine is also viable.

Rotom-S fits on balance and offense teams as an entry hazard remover and pivot. Common VoltTurn teammates like Silvally-Dark, Alolan Persian, and Uxie can form a pivot core with Rotom-S to safely bring in wallbreakers such as Jynx and Shiftry. Toxic cripples Rotom-S, so Toxic-immune partners such as Qwilfish and Clefairy are greatly appreciated; Rotom-S in turn provides them with a switch-in to Ground-type attacks. Knock Off hinders Rotom-S's ability to remove entry hazards, so Knock Off absorbers such as Silvally formes, Qwilfish, and Skuntank help immensely. Rotom-S is unable to deal with hard-hitting wallbreakers such as Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Rapidash, so strong revenge killers such as Froslass, Alolan Persian, and Choice Scarf Sawk are all great teammates.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Rotom-S's decent Speed along with an excellent offensive typing give it a niche as a stallbreaker and cleaner with Nasty Plot. Substitute allows Rotom-S to avoid crippling status from passive Pokemon such as Clefairy and Altaria, which, in conjunction with its STAB Thunderbolt, lets it beat the only Unaware user in the tier in Pyukumuku. Pain Split, on the other hand, gives Rotom-S more longevity against weak attackers without status such as Cofagrigus, Galarian Stunfisk, and Uxie.

Rotom-S is fits on offensive teams for its stallbreaking and cleaning capabilities. Teammates such as Silvally formes, Kangaskhan, and Basculin appreciate Rotom-S dealing with bulky Pokemon such as Pyukumuku, Tangela, and Altaria. Faster offensive Pokemon such as Kangaskhan, Rapidash, and Silvally formes are able to threaten Rotom-S, so switch-ins such as Cofagrigus, Piloswine, and Galarian Stunfisk and fast attackers like Alolan Persian, Basculin, and Choice Scarf Sawk are vital for it. Ground-type Pokemon such as Piloswine and Rhydon are able to stomach an unboosted attack from Rotom-S, so switch-ins such as Tangela and Miltank are appreciated.

Uxie.comments:
Other Options

Uxie can run a specially defensive spread on its defensive set to better handle special attackers such as Ninetales and Manectric at the expense of switching into Sawk, Rhydon, and Gurdurr. Leftovers is an alternative to Colbur Berry on Uxie's defensive set, providing reliable recovery and improving its longevity. However, this makes Uxie vulnerable to Knock Off. Thunder Wave is a viable alternative to Knock Off that cripples faster attackers such as Thievul and Silvally formes, letting Uxie's teammates take them on more easily. Defensive Uxie can also run Choice Scarf with Trick and 64 Speed EVs, letting it outspeed up to Alolan Persian and cripple a potential entry hazard remover like Articuno or Coalossal. However, Uxie can get a crippling item like Skuntank's Black Sludge or Rotom's Choice Specs, or even become setup fodder for Silvally formes due to their Trick immunity. Memento is an alternative for the defensive pivot set, blocking Defog and bringing in a teammate more safely than U-turn, but Uxie often can't fit it. Encore can be used to punish Pokemon that otherwise freely set up on Uxie like Galarian Rapidash and Ninetales.

Checks and Counters

Ghost-types: Uxie is threatened by attackers such as Rotom and Gourgeist-S. However, most of them take great damage from Knock Off and STAB moves, meaning Uxie can pressure them on the switch.

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Thievul, Silvally-Dark, and Skuntank threaten Uxie with their super effective STAB moves, block Future Sight, and can sponge boosted Draining Kiss. However, most take heavy damage from U-turn, and Colbur Berry Uxie can afford to take a hit.

Bulky Setup Sweepers: Defensive sweepers such as Alcremie and Spiritomb easily set up on the weak Uxie. Most of them can also beat Uxie in a setup war.

Wallbreakers and Stallbreakers: Wallbreakers such as Thwackey and Basculin can use Uxie's passivity to threaten its whole team with their powerful moves. However, they dislike losing Choice Band or Choice Specs to Knock Off. Faster Taunt users such as Alolan Persian can shut down Uxie's utility and take advantage of it with Toxic.

Steel-types: Setup Uxie sets have a very hard time breaking through Steel-types such as Klinklang due to its low damage output. They can easily break Uxie's Substitute and remove Uxie before it is boosted enough.

Haze Articuno and Pyukumuku: Haze Articuno and Unaware Pyukumuku can wall most setup Uxie. However, Pyukumuku has to be wary of Stored Power's increased Base Power.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Uxie can act as a terrifying late-game cleaner with its Nasty Plot set. Substitute lets it avoid status such as Toxic from Articuno and Altaria, dodge Knock Off from Tangela and Clefairy, and sponge hits from weak attackers like Clefairy lacking Seismic Toss and Stunfisk. Psyshock is preferred over Psychic as a STAB move to get around special walls like Articuno and Clefairy more easily. Draining Kiss lets Uxie break through Dark-types like Thievul and Morpeko after a boost and provides coveted recovery.

Uxie is a great late-game cleaner for bulkier teams that can weaken its checks over time. Therefore, entry hazard support, especially Spikes from setters such as Coalossal and Qwilfish, is invaluable. Knock Off support is similarly valuable for removing Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers, the latter being the only form of recovery of Steel-types that check Uxie like Klinklang. Toxic users such as Altaria and Rapidash cripple the likes of Haze Articuno, Alcremie, and Musharna to help Uxie break through them. Uxie can also fit well with other defensive sweepers like Spiritomb and Alcremie, weakening each other’s checks and forcing Trick uses to ensure one of them can sweep.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
Uxie is a premier defensive pivot in VoltTurn teams due to its incredible role compression as the only viable Pokemon with both U-turn and Stealth Rock. Additionally, Uxie's incredible bulk lets it reliably check threats like Sawk and Silvally-Poison. Levitate also helps in that regard, avoiding chip damage from Spikes and giving it switch-in opportunities on Rhydon and Piloswine. Yawn allows Uxie to avoid being setup fodder and force out entry hazard removers like Altaria, Articuno, and Coalossal and therefore keep Stealth Rock up. Knock Off lets Uxie remove important items like Heavy-Duty Boots from Articuno, Cramorant, and Altaria and Eviolite from Piloswine, Rhydon, and Tangela. Future Sight lets Uxie's partners threaten their checks with the extra, delayed damage. Colbur Berry allows Uxie to counter Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr by weakening their Knock Off; it also lets Uxie take a hit from strong Dark-type wallbreakers such as Thievul, Silvally-Dark, and Shiftry and pivot out with a super effective U-turn.

Uxie can form a VoltTurn core with other pivots such as Alolan Persian, Rotom, and Silvally formes. Such cores are beneficial to wallbreakers that prefer safe switches like Silvally formes, Thievul, and Sawk. Dark-types like Silvally-Dark and Skuntank value Uxie's ability to wall Fighting-types like Sawk and can, in return, threaten Ghost-types like Gourgeist-S and Rotom. Physical wallbreakers like Kangaskhan and Silvally formes appreciate Future Sight threatening physical walls such as Miltank, Qwilfish, and Tangela. Uxie lacks recovery and gets quickly worn down by Toxic; other walls like Clefairy and Qwilfish can absorb status and take attacks that Uxie can't afford to take. Clefairy also has Aromatherapy to cure Uxie of any status. Pokemon like Poliwrath and Jynx pressure hazard removers like Coalossal, Articuno, and Altaria, helping keep up Uxie's Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Uxie finds a spot in Electric Terrain teams as a Calm Mind sweeper. Stored Power has insane power after Calm Mind and Electric Seed, letting Uxie break through bulkier foes like Articuno and Pyukumuku. Draining Kiss lets Uxie threaten Dark-types like Thievul and Silvally-Dark. Rest is Uxie's best form of recovery, also letting it deal with status from special walls like Articuno lacking Haze and Clefairy. The given spread allows Uxie to outspeed Timid Exeggutor.

Pincurchin is a necessary partner for Electric Surge. Other Electric Seed sweepers like Musharna, Swoobat, Drifblim, and Galarian Rapidash can weaken shared checks, forming a Calm Mind spam core. Electric-types like Raichu and Manectric also appreciate Electric Terrain and can break through special walls, making it easier for Uxie and the other Calm Mind users. In return, Uxie can set up on Ground-types that wall Raichu and Manectric thanks to Levitate.

sets.name: Offense Lead
sets.description:
Uxie's great Speed and amazing bulk make it a great supporter for offensive teams, being able to set Stealth Rock and then cripple the opposing Pokemon with Memento, Encore, or Yawn, giving switching and setup opportunities to teammates. Since this set isn't running any offensive move, Mental Herb is the preferred item to not get completely invalidated by Taunt users like Skuntank, Golbat, and Alolan Persian.

Setup spam offense teams really enjoy Uxie's role compression, creating setup opportunities and providing Stealth Rock. Therefore, offensive setup users like Crustle, Klinklang, and Silvally formes make for great partners. Pokemon that can advantage of Taunt users that Uxie invites in, such as Alcremie, Double Dance Rhydon, and Rotom-S, are appreciated. Gourgeist-S can prevent Rapid Spin attempts, while Taunt users like Skuntank and Qwilfish deny Defog.

sets.name: Sun Setter
sets.description:
Thanks to its great bulk and higher Speed than common Taunt users such as Skuntank, Qwilfish, and Sawk, Uxie is capable of reliably setting sun and Stealth Rock several times. U-turn brings sun attackers safely onto the field. Yawn forces out foes that would attempt to set up on Uxie such as Skuntank and Ninetales, which works well with Uxie's fast U-turn. Memento can alternatively be used to provide similar opportunities to Yawn and U-turn in one turn at the cost of sacrificing Uxie.

Sun sweepers such as Shiftry, Leafeon, Ivysaur, and Rapidash love Uxie's ability to reliably set sun. Prankster Liepard is a reliable secondary weather setter to support the team. An offensive sun setter such as Exeggutor creates more opportunities to set it up.

Liepard.comments:
Other Options

Liepard has other useful support options like Taunt and Thunder Wave; however, it lacks room for them.

Checks and Counters

Fighting- and Fairy-types: Sawk, Poliwrath, and Alcremie take little from Liepard's moves and OHKO it back with their STAB moves. Gurdurr easily tanks Dark Pulse and OHKOes Liepard after slight chip damage.

Special Walls: Nasty Plot sets need several boosts to break through special walls such as Articuno and Malamar, which can stall Liepard with Toxic or outright OHKO it with their attack respectively.

Dark-types: Dark-types like Shiftry, Silvally-Dark, and Skuntank are immune to Prankster, resist Liepard's STAB moves, and defeat it with their secondary STAB or coverage moves. However, they have to watch out for U-turn.

Strong Attackers: Because of its poor bulk, Liepard gets OHKOed by strong attackers like Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Basculin. Liepard is forced out by them unless it manages to lock them into unfavorable moves with Encore.

sets.name: Sun Setter
sets.description:
The combination of Prankster and Sunny Day lets Liepard act as an excellent mid-game sun setter. U-turn lets it pivot into a teammate that benefits from sun, such as Shiftry and Ivysaur. Knock Off helps Liepard further support its teammates by removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Articuno and Altaria. Encore locks foes such as Silvally-Poison and Uxie into unfavorable moves like Work Up and Stealth Rock, giving Liepard free turns to set up sun and pivot with U-turn. Heat Rock is necessary to provide as many sun turns as possible to Liepard's partners.

Liepard is a must-have on sun teams and is appreciated by sun sweepers such as Shiftry, Ivysaur, and Rapidash. Uxie's sun setter set also fits well on sun teams for its capacity to reliably set Stealth Rock and sun for its team. Furthermore, a third sun setter such as Exeggutor provides more possibilities to set up sun.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Thanks to its high Speed tier and access to Nasty Plot and a pseudo-priority move in Prankster Copycat, Liepard separates itself from other Nasty Plot sweepers such as Skuntank and Alolan Persian. Copycat is mainly used to call Dark Pulse and prevent faster foes like Froslass, Choice Scarf Rotom, and Basculin from revenge killing a Nasty Plot-boosted Liepard. Encore provides Liepard setup opportunities by locking foes such as Piloswine and Articuno into undesirable moves. Heavy-Duty Boots are preferred on VoltTurn teams to help Liepard avoid entry hazards and potentially pivot. Black Glasses are an alternative that makes up for Liepard's average Special Attack, making it require less chip damage to clean.

VoltTurn support from pivots such as Uxie, Articuno, and Rotom helps Liepard come on the field in spite of its lackluster bulk. Special wallbreakers such as Ninetales, Rotom, and Basculin can soften opposing special walls in order to let Liepard clean late game. Checks to Fighting-types such as Uxie, Qwilfish, and Rotom-S take on Sawk and Gurdurr, which force Liepard out. Likewise, checks to Fairy-types like Klinklang, Silvally-Poison, and Rapidash are great partners that handle Alcremie and Clefairy. Checks to Dark-types such as Alcremie, Gurdurr, and Sawk are also appreciated, as Silvally-Dark and Skuntank can take on Liepard. Kangaskhan is a threat because of Fake Out outprioritizing Copycat, letting it easily revenge kill a weakened Liepard; therefore, checks like Uxie, Tangela, and Cofagrigus are appreciated.

Unfezant.comments:
Other Options

A utility set with Heavy-Duty Boots, Roost, and Defog is feasible, as this set gives Unfezant reliable recovery and allows it to be an offensive entry hazard remover. However, the listed sets more naturally play to Unfezant's strengths, and this set struggles even more against hazard setters like Coalossal, Rhydon, and Qwilfish due to its reliance on Heavy-Duty Boots.

Checks and Counters

Rock- and Steel-types: Rhydon, Coalossal, Perrserker, and Klinklang resist Unfezant's STAB moves, fear none of its coverage, and threaten OHKOs or significant damage with their STAB moves. Rhydon and Coalossal can also set or remove entry hazards, and Coalossal's Flame Body deters Unfezant from pivoting or attacking. However, Perrserker and Klinklang can be worn down by the Choice Band set and fail to reliably switch in later on.

Stealth Rock: Unfezant’s weakness to Stealth Rock and recoil from Brave Bird quickly wear it down, causing it to faint rather quickly.

Electric-types: Electric-types like Rotom formes and Stunfisk can stomach a hit from both Unfezant sets and threaten to OHKO in return with their super effective STAB moves. Stunfisk also has Static to discourage Unfezant from pivoting with U-turn. However, Rotom must be aware of Night Slash from the Choice Band set.

Faster Offensive Threats: While none of them can safely switch in, Pokemon like Jynx, Rapidash, and Choice Scarf Sawk and Rotom can KO Choice Band Unfezant with minimal to no prior chip damage due to its mediocre bulk. However, they must also be aware of Choice Scarf sets, which they can't check.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Unfezant is a powerful wallbreaker, able to devastate teams without sturdy Flying-resistant Pokemon such as Rhydon or Coalossal with Choice Band-boosted STAB Brave Bird. U-turn enables Unfezant to pivot out against Stunfisk, Piloswine, and Klinklang, keeping momentum and chipping them. Quick Attack finishes off weakened faster foes like Cinccino and Basculin. Night Slash lets Unfezant OHKO Rotom. Facade instead becomes a very powerful STAB move if Unfezant gets statused. Super Luck gives it better chances to break through Double Dance Alcremie if the latter has gained a Defense boost prior.

Unfezant fits well in offensive teams due to its great power, good Speed tier, and mediocre bulk. It struggles to break past sturdy Flying-resistant Pokemon like Klinklang and Coalossal and could potentially lose momentum against them. Water- and Electric-types pair particularly well, as Pokemon like Wishiwashi, Basculin, and Raichu can force them out with their STAB or coverage moves and bring Unfezant in safely with their pivot moves. In return, Unfezant can form a VoltTurn core with them and force out Grass-types such as Eldegoss, Tangela, and Gourgeist-S, which pressure them. Spikes users, such as Qwilfish and Coalossal, wear down its checks, many of which lack reliable recovery. Entry hazard control from the likes of Eldegoss, Rotom, and Hattrem can ameliorate its Stealth Rock weakness. Hattrem in particular synergizes well, as it can threaten Rhydon and Stunfisk with Giga Drain. Special wallbreakers like Rotom, Basculin, and Jynx can overwhelm physical walls like Rhydon, Pyukumuku, and Miltank that Unfezant has difficulty breaking through. Other Flying-type wallbreakers, like Silvally-Flying and Rotom-S, can overwhelm their checks with repeated STAB Flying-type moves and coverage options.

Gurdurr.comments:
Other Options

Defog is an option to turn Gurdurr into an entry hazard remover that poses good matchups against common entry hazard setters like Piloswine and Rhydon, but it generally has difficulty fitting the move. Stone Edge targets foes like Rotom-S, Altaria, and Articuno.

Checks and Counters

Flying-types: Although they do not appreciate Knock Off removing their Heavy-Duty Boots, Flying-types such as Rotom-S, Altaria, and Cramorant can threaten to KO Gurdurr.

Physical Walls: Physical walls such as Altaria and Tangela are able to take hits from Gurdurr and pressure it with their STAB attacks. However, they should be wary of Knock Off. Alcremie is a notable foe that is able to take Gurdurr's STAB options and Knock Off and pressure it with its Fairy-type moves.

Chip Damage and Knock Off: It is easy to cripple and wear down Gurdurr, as it is reliant on Drain Punch recovery and Eviolite to check its foes.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
Gurdurr is a notable tank in ZU thanks to its good bulk and access to decent recovery through Drain Punch. This recovery lets Gurdurr more consistently set up, letting it accumulate multiple boosts. Gurdurr can utilize Bulk Up mid- or late-game against passive foes like Stunfisk and Coalossal. Knock Off cripples switch-ins such as Tangela, Altaria, and Rotom-S. Mach Punch allows Gurdurr to revenge kill foes such as Shiftry and Kangaskhan. 252 HP and 60 Defense EVs ensure that Gurdurr will only be 3HKOed by Kangaskhan's Double-Edge, while 252 HP and 60 Special Defense EVs allow it to live Choice Specs Hydro Pump from Basculin after Stealth Rock damage. Guts lets Gurdurr absorb Will-O-Wisp from Rapidash and Toxic from Pyukumuku to empower its attacks.

Gurdurr fits on both bulky offense and balance teams due to its solid bulk and ability to generate pressure with both Bulk Up and Mach Punch. Gurdurr appreciates strong offensive support from its teammates to keep initiative throughout the battle, as it is otherwise prone to being worn down by common VoltTurn cores. Wallbreakers such as Rapidash, Silvally formes, and Thievul can threaten physical walls such as Tangela, Gourgeist-XL, and Qwilfish, enabling Gurdurr to better threaten them late-game. Pokemon such as Rotom and Exeggutor benefit from Gurdurr revenge killing foes such as Silvally-Dark and Shiftry with Mach Punch; in return, they can threaten Flying-types such as Rotom-S and Cramorant that trouble it.

Throh.comments:
Other Options

Throh can run a wallbreaker set with Flame Orb and Facade; however, it lacks a spammable powerful STAB move, since it is limited to Superpower and Storm Throw. Additionally, Sawk and Silvally-Fighting are usually preferred for their higher Speed tiers and better wallbreaking capabilities. Throh can also attempt to use a Bulk Up set with either Mold Breaker or Guts, with the former giving it the ability to ignore Pyukumuku's Unaware; however, Gurdurr is better at this role due to having Drain Punch for recovery and Mach Punch for priority. A physically defensive set is more effective at checking the likes of Silvally formes, Sawk, and Kangaskhan, but Throh struggles to absorb status without a specially defensive spread.

Checks and Counters

Ghost-types: Pokemon like Spiritomb, Rotom, and Gourgeist-XL are immune to Throh's STAB moves and can sponge Knock Off. Spiritomb can set up on Throh, while Rotom and Gourgeist-XL annoy it with status. However, Rotom should be careful switching into Knock Off.

Flying-types: Flying-types like Altaria, Rotom-S, and Cramorant resist Throh's STAB moves and can retaliate back with their super effective STAB moves. However, they despise losing their valuable Heavy-Duty Boots to Knock Off.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types like Alcremie, Galarian Rapidash, and Shiinotic resist Throh's moves and can threaten it with their super effective STAB moves. Although Clefairy cannot break through Throh, it can cripple Throh with Knock Off or pivot with Teleport into a check.

Physical Wallbreakers: Even if Throh's physical bulk is far from lacking, its reliance on Rest lets it often get overwhelmed by physical wallbreakers like Froslass, Silvally formes, and Sawk.

Psychic-types: Psychic-types like Uxie, Swoobat, and Musharna resist Throh's STAB moves, don't take much from Knock Off, and threaten it with their STAB moves or Future Sight. Jynx can also break past Throh, but it cannot safely switch into Throh's attacks.

sets.name: Special Wall
sets.description:
Throh is a very bulky special wall that works especially well on Spikes-stacking teams. Circle Throw lets it phaze switch-ins, which pairs well with entry hazard support. Knock Off cripples checks like Altaria, Alcremie, and Tangela, hits Ghost-types like Rotom and Gourgeist-S, and removes Heavy-Duty Boots, which is appreciated on entry hazard-stacking teams. Rest is Throh's only form of recovery; thanks to Sleep Talk and Guts, Throh acts as a status absorber and lacks passivity while asleep. The given EV spread ets Throh outspeed uninvested base 50 Speed Pokemon such as Piloswine.

Throh appreciates entry hazard support a lot, especially Spikes from setters such as Qwilfish and Coalossal. Spinblockers like Rotom and Gourgeist formes and fast Taunt users like Alolan Persian, Golbat, and Qwilfish can keep up these entry hazards. Rapid Spin users such as Kabutops and Morpeko also make for great partners. Additionally, most of them help handle physical attackers Throh struggles to beat such as Sawk and Silvally-Poison. Despite being a good special wall, Throh appreciates being paired with Pokemon that can handle Volt Switch like Stunfisk and Manectric; they prevent it from getting chipped by Electric-types like Rotom, Manectric, and Raichu and losing momentum.

Sawk.comments:
Other Options

Poison Jab lets Sawk 2HKO Alcremie and Clefairy, but this requires giving up one of its other coverage moves, which generally isn't preferred because they target more Pokemon.

Checks and Counters

Ghost-types: Spiritomb, Gourgeist-Super, and Sableye can switch into any of Sawk's attacks with ease. The former can also set up on Sawk with Calm Mind.

Physical Walls: Tangela, Uxie, and Altaria can switch into Sawk and either cripple it with their status moves or deal significant damage with their STAB moves. Tangela and Altaria must be careful of switching into Knock Off and Stone Edge, respectively, as Choice Band Sawk can 2HKO Tangela if it has lost its Eviolite and can KO Altaria with some prior chip damage. While Qwilfish must be wary of switching into Earthquake, it can easily switch into Close Combat and wear Sawk down with Rocky Helmet.

Faster Threats: Faster attackers such as Rotom, Basculin, and Froslass can revenge kill Sawk if it has been slightly worn down. However, none of them can afford to risk directly switching into one of Sawk's attacks.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
With a solid Speed tier and its incredibly high attacking power, Sawk makes for an excellent revenge killer that fits well on offense and balance teams. Choice Scarf allows Sawk to threaten foes such as Alolan Persian, Kangaskhan, and Froslass. Knock Off targets Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Rotom, Gourgeist-S, and Uxie while also crippling common switch-ins such as Alcremie, Clefairy, and Tangela. Earthquake hits Poison-types such as Silvally-Poison, Qwilfish, and Skuntank. Stone Edge lets Sawk deal with Flying-types such as Rotom-S, Altaria, and Golbat. Mold Breaker allows Sawk to hit Levitate users such as Uxie and Rotom with Earthquake. Alternatively, Inner Focus allows Sawk to beat Qwilfish with Earthquake, as Inner Focus nullifies its Intimidate, and not flinch from Kangaskhan's Fake Out. However, don't expect to get free turns from Kangaskhan trying to flinch you, as the opponent should notice the absent Mold Breaker activation message.

While Sawk has super effective coverage for Pokemon that resist or are immune to Close Combat, it still needs physical walls such as Uxie, Tangela, and Altaria to be weakened in order to KO them and successfully clean. Therefore, special attackers such as Skuntank, Rotom, and Basculin that can deal with them make for great partners. Entry hazard setters such as Rhydon, Piloswine, and Qwilfish help to wear down Sawk's common switch-ins, as most do not have access to reliable recovery. Pivots such as Uxie, Rotom-S, and Alolan Persian circumvent Sawk's mediocre bulk by safely bringing it onto the field, with the former also having access to Future Sight, which dissuades Poison-types from switching in.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Sawk forgoes Choice Scarf's increase in Speed for more wallbreaking power, letting Close Combat net 2HKOs on neutral physical walls like Pyukumuku and Gurdurr. Knock Off pressures Ghost- and Psychic-types like Rotom and Uxie while also crippling common switch-ins such as Tangela; Close Combat threatens a 2HKO on Tangela once its Eviolite has been removed. Earthquake punishes Poison-types like Qwilfish and Silvally-Poison, while Stone Edge nails Flying-types such as Rotom-S and Altaria.

Choice Band Sawk is vulnerable to being revenge killed by faster Flying- and Psychic-types such as Rotom-S and Jynx, so switch-ins such as Rhydon and Articuno are appreciated. These Pokemon also have the added benefit of providing entry hazards to help wear down its switch-ins. Special setup sweepers such as Ninetales and Alcremie benefit greatly from Sawk's ability to break past specially defensive walls such as Coalossal and Miltank. Sawk also appreciates the removal of Ghost-types, so pairing it with Dark-types like Skuntank, Shiftry, and Alolan Persian is a good idea. Future Sight Uxie is a great partner, as it punishes the physical walls such as Tangela and Altaria that switch in on Sawk and can also pivot Sawk in safely with U-turn. Sawk can also weaken the aforementioned walls into the KO range of physical cleaners like Rapidash and Swords Dance Silvally formes.

Beheeyem.comments:
Other Options

A bulky Nasty Plot set with Recover allows Beheeyem to wallbreak outside of Trick Room and better wield Analytic, though Beheeyem becomes even easier to revenge kill because it lacks a way to circumvent its low Speed.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Dark-types like Silvally-Dark, Thievul, Choice Band Spiritomb, and Shiftry can switch into Psychic and OHKO Beheeyem with minimal to no prior chip damage, especially if Beheeyem has used its Power Herb. The latter two in particular can OHKO Beheeyem with Sucker Punch, forcing it out most of the time even under Trick Room.

Steel-types: Klinklang has enough bulk to stomach at least one hit from Beheeyem and deal massive damage in return. However, it cannot switch in safely.

Special Walls: Special walls like Clefairy and Stunfisk can take a hit from Beheeyem and stall out Trick Room turns with their terrific bulk. Clefairy can recover damage off with Soft-Boiled and fish for Special Attack drops with Moonblast.

Kangaskhan: Although it cannot switch in, Kangaskhan can repeatedly use Fake Out and waste Trick Room turns, additionally whittling Beheeyem down. After Beheeyem has been weakened enough, Kangaskhan can use Sucker Punch and defeat it.

Faster Wallbreakers: Without Trick Room, Beheeyem's merely passable bulk and poor defensive typing leave it very vulnerable to strong Pokemon that can outspeed it, such as Rotom and Jynx.

sets.name: Trick Room
sets.description:
Thanks to Beheeyem's sky-high Special Attack stat, terrible Speed stat, and access to Trick Room, it is a staple on said archetype. Meteor Beam OHKOes Pokemon that can switch into Psychic like Alolan Persian, Skuntank, and Thievul, OHKOes specially defensive Pokemon like Articuno and Coalossal, and boosts its Special Attack stat without wasting a Trick Room turn on setup when used with Power Herb. Thunderbolt OHKOes Cramorant while 2HKOing Articuno at +1. It is also Beheeyem's strongest spammable option against Dark- and Steel-types. Analytic takes advantage of how well Beheeyem forces switches, and it exploits Beeheeyem's very low Speed in the rare instances it attacks outside of Trick Room.

Due to Beheeyem's awful Speed, poor defensive typing, and merely decent bulk, it should mainly be used on dedicated Trick Room teams, as otherwise other Psychic-types and special wallbreakers outclass it. Other Trick Room setters, like Gourgeist-XL, Uxie, and Trevenant, can provide more chances for Beheeyem to attack without needing to set up Trick Room first, and teammates that lack Trick Room especially appreciate these chances. These teammates include Bouffalant, Flame Orb Throh, and Rhydon, which benefit from Beheeyem's wallbreaking and Trick Room, enabling them to more easily break holes against the opposition or clean late-game.

Cryogonal.comments:
Other Options

Rapid Spin can be used over Defog on entry hazard stacking teams to avoid removing Cryogonal's own entry hazards. Haze is also useful against special setup sweepers such as Skuntank and Nasty Plot Rotom. A dual screens set with Reflect, Light Screen, and Explosion has a niche on hyper offense teams.

Checks and Counters

Physical Attackers: Physical attackers such as Kangaskhan, Rhydon, and Silvally formes threaten Cryogonal due to its low physical bulk.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Sawk can threaten to OHKO Cryogonal. Specifically, Choice Scarf Sawk outspeeds Cryogonal and OHKOes it, while Gurdurr easily tanks Freeze-Dry and threatens Cryogonal with Drain Punch.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash resist Freeze-Dry and can force Cryogonal out.

Steel-types: Klinklang and Alolan Dugtrio tank Freeze-Dry and can retaliate with their STAB attacks. However, they do not appreciate taking a Knock Off.

Item Removal: Knock Off users like Uxie, Alolan Persian and Clefairy and Trick users like Rotom and Jynx can threaten to cripple Cryogonal by removing its Heavy-Duty Boots, which makes it vulnerable to Stealth Rock and lowers its ability to switch in.

sets.name: Special Wall
sets.description:
Cryogonal is a fast, niche Defogger in the metagame that has great special bulk and can offensively pressure Qwilfish. Cryogonal also performs well as a specially defensive wall, checking prevalent special attackers such as Articuno, Rotom formes, and Jynx. It has access to reliable recovery in Recover and great utility with the combination of Toxic and Knock Off.

Nonetheless, Cryogonal's low Defense stat and poor defensive typing make it vulnerable to a majority of physical attackers. Altaria can help Cryogonal check both Fire- and Fighting-type moves. Tangela can also check physical attackers such as Sawk, Kangaskhan, and Gurdurr, which force out Cryogonal. In return, Cryogonal counters special attackers such as Rotom formes and Appletun. On balance builds, Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash are great partners for Cryogonal, handling Steel-types such as Perrserker and Klinklang; in return, Cryogonal is able to pressure its checks such as Altaria and bulky Water-types like Qwilfish. Water-types like Qwilfish and Poliwrath help check Fire-types such as Rapidash and Ninetales, which annoy Cryogonal. Bulky Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Throh also pair well with Cryogonal, threatening Steel-types.

Stunfisk.comments:
Other Options

Rest provides Stunfisk with recovery and lets it remove status, but it makes Stunfisk even more passive. Thunder Wave provides a more reliable method of slowing foes like Sawk and Silvally formes, while Protect synergizes with Toxic and Leftovers, wearing down foes and providing Stunfisk with more recovery. However, Stunfisk often has difficulty fitting either move.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Grass-types like Tangela, Thwackey, and Appletun threaten Stunfisk with their attacks or status and force it out. However, they do not appreciate Toxic.

Water-types: Although they cannot directly switch into Discharge or Toxic, Water-types like Basculin, Poliwrath, and Pyukumuku can effectively handle Stunfisk.

Ice-types: Despite its great special bulk, Stunfisk is vulnerable to powerful Ice-types like Froslass, Abomasnow, and Jynx.

Ground-types: Ground-types like Rhydon and Piloswine target Stunfisk's lack of reliable recovery and heavily damage or KO it with their strong attacks.

Strong Physical Attackers: Strong physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Sawk heavily pressure Stunfisk with their attacks, although they dislike Static.

Residual Damage: Stunfisk's lack of reliable recovery leaves it vulnerable to Spikes and Toxic from foes such as Qwilfish, Rapidash, and Clefairy.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Stunfisk is a notable specially defensive wall and Stealth Rock setter in ZU that has good matchups against common threats like Rotom, Skuntank, and Manectric. Toxic wears down switch-ins like Tangela, Rhydon, and Piloswine and Defoggers like Articuno and Rotom formes. Earth Power prevents Stunfisk from being passive against prominent special attackers like Manectric, Skuntank, and Ninetales. Discharge allows Stunfisk to spread paralysis and deal with most Defoggers, while Foul Play lets it handle Substitute + Nasty Plot Rotom and physical setup sweepers like Thwackey, which may try to take advantage of Stunfisk to safely set up. Static punishes physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Klinklang, and it can also give Stunfisk a chance to cripple checks like physical Basculin and Thwackey in an emergency situation.

Stunfisk fits primarily on balance and bulky offense teams and provides valuable role compression. Grass-types like Tangela, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S handle Water- and Ground-types like Poliwrath and Rhydon; in return, Stunfisk can take on Poison-types like Silvally-Poison and Skuntank for them. Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales pressure the aforementioned Grass-types, as well as Ice-types like Articuno and Frolass, for Stunfisk. As Stunfisk has a poor matchup against other Stealth Rock setters like Rhydon and Piloswine, it is adviseable to pair it with Water-types like Poliwrath, Basculin, and Cramorant; Cramorant is a notable partner that can provide Defog and check powerful foes like Sawk while benefitting greatly from Stunfisk dealing with Electric-types. Toxic absorbers like Altaria and Qwilfish prevent Stunfisk from getting worn down; a Toxic Spikes absorber like Silvally-Poison or Qwilfish is likewise helpful. Cleric support from partners like Clefairy and Alcremie helps Stunfisk remain healthy, especially on bulkier teams.

Stunfisk-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Snap Trap traps and chips down targets while synergizing with Yawn to inflict foes with sleep. However, having one of these moves reduces Galarian Stunfisk's coverage and utility in other areas and leaves it unable to deal with Substitute + Nasty Plot Rotom formes; they should only been used in specific situations. Thunder Wave cripples and forces out faster foes like Kangaskhan and Silvally formes; however, it leaves Stunfisk Galarian unable to punish Ground-types. Protect allows Galarian Stunfisk to gain more recovery from Leftovers and lets it scout Choice item users such as Sawk and Rotom. Rest is also used as a recovery option, but it is considerably niche and only fits on select teams. Rest is best used when paired with Heal Bell support from Articuno, Clefairy, or Altaria on stall teams.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Water-types such as Basculin, Cramorant, and Poliwrath handle Galarian Stunfisk with their super effective STAB moves.

Ground-types: Ground-types such as Rhydon, Piloswine, and Silvally-Gound force out Galarian Stunfisk out, with the former two using that opportunity to set up Stealth Rock and the latter setting up with Swords Dance.

Fighting-type Pokemon and Coverage: Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr threaten Galarian Stunfisk with their super effective STAB moves, while Cofagrigus can set up with Iron Defense and KO it with Body Press.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash threaten Galarian Stunfisk, although they cannot safely switch in due to Galarian Stunfisk's Rock / Ground coverage.

Strong Wallbreakers: While Galarian Stunfisk does have great bulk, it can easily get overwhelmed by strong setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Shiftry and Nasty Plot Rotom.

Item Removal: Pokemon carrying Knock Off or Trick, such as Uxie, Rotom, and Thwackey, can remove Galarian Stunfisk's main form of recovery in Leftovers, limiting its effectiveness as a special wall.

Hazards: Although Galarian Stunfisk takes little damage from Stealth Rock, Spikes chips down Galarian Stunfisk over time, limiting its switch-ins and effectiveness as a special wall.

sets.name: Special Wall
sets.description:
Galarian Stunfisk is a niche Stealth Rock setter in the metagame thanks to its great defensive stats and great defensive typing that lets it wall threats such as Rotom formes. Rock Slide hits Pokemon such as Cramorant, Articuno, and the aforementioned Rotom formes; Rock Slide is more consistent than Stone Edge and preferred due to its higher accuracy and PP. Curse turns Galarian Stunfisk into a threatening late-game cleaner while also making up for its passivity. Yawn forces switches from Pokemon that wall Galarian Stunfisk, such as Uxie and Tangela. Foul Play deals significant damage to Swords Dance users such as Silvally formes.

Galarian Stunfisk is a decent pick on balance and stall teams thanks to it compressing the role of an Electric immunity, Stealth Rock setter, and special wall. Bulky Water-types such as Cramorant and Poliwrath are great partners to Galarian Stunfisk, as they can take on Water-types such as Basculin and Poliwrath, which threaten Galarian Stunfisk, while also benefitting from Galarian Stunfisk's Electric immunity. Grass-types are also great partners to cover Galarian Stunfisk's weaknesses, with Appletun covering its weaknesses to Ground, Water, and Fire, while Gourgeist-S and Trevenant cover its weaknesses to Ground, Water, and Fighting. Uxie can also work as a partner, as it is resistant to Fighting and immune to Ground. Spikes stacking teams also appreciate Galarian Stunfisk's ability to force switches with Yawn, with a Spikes setter such as Qwilfish also covering Galarian Stunfisk's weakness to Fighting.

Bouffalant.comments:
Other Options

A Choice Band set provides Bouffalant with immediate wallbreaking power and also has the element of surprise. Reckless is used to further increase the power of Head Charge. However, this loses the niche of Grass immunity and faces heavy competition from weaker yet more versatile Normal-types in Kangaskhan and Silvally.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Fighting-type Pokemon such as Sawk, Silvally-Fighting, and Poliwrath all threaten to OHKO Bouffalant with their powerful STAB attacks.

Physical Walls: Miltank and Qwilfish can wear down Bouffalant with Rocky Helmet damage, which adds to Head Charge recoil. Alolan Persian can survive a few hits and prevent setup thanks to Foul Play.

Strong Faster Pokemon: Strong, faster Pokemon such as Silvally-Dark and Basculin can hit Boufflant hard, preventing it from setting up.

Ghost-types: Sableye and Gourgeist-XL can sponge Bouffalant's attacks and prevent setup with Foul Play and Will-O-Wisp. Rotom can also threaten Bouffalant with Will-O-Wisp but doesn't take Throat Chop very well.

sets.name: Sap Sipper Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Bouffalant finds its niche in ZU as a bulky wallbreaker with a great ability in Sap Sipper. Sap Sipper allows Bouffalant to prey on ZU's Grass-types, such as the common blanket physical wall Tangela, using them as setup fodder with Substitute and Swords Dance. In addition, Bouffalant checks offensive Grass-type threats in Thwackey and Gourgeist-S. Head Charge is Bouffalant's standard STAB move thanks to its high power. Facade is sometimes used over Substitute and takes advantage of status. This then frees up Close Combat as a coverage option, which hits Pokemon that resist Bouffalant's STAB move such as Rhydon, Klingklang, and Coalossal. Throat Chop is used to hit Ghost-types like Rotom, Gourgeist formes, and Trevenant. The EV spread allows Bouffalant to outspeed uninvested Tangela and Alcremie whilst increasing bulk.

Bouffalant fits well on balance and bulky offense teams, helping break down defensive teams that rely on passive Pokemon to deal damage. Thwackey is a great partner for Bouffalant, as it can lure in Tangela before pivoting out with U-turn, bring in Bouffalant safely, and provide additional passive recovery on top of Leftovers. Kabutops and Morpeko are other pivots that can force Grass-types in. Strong special attackers such as Basculin, Thievul, and Appletun can help break through other physically bulky Pokemon such as Rhydon, Qwilfish, and Miltank. Uxie and Qwillfish can compress the roles of entry hazard setter and switch-in to Fighting-type attacks that threaten Bouffalant. Dark-type Pokemon such as Silvally-Dark and Skuntank can help pressure Ghost-types like Rotom and Sableye, which are immune to Bouffalant's STAB moves. Lastly, late-game cleaners such as Choice Scarf Sawk, Thwackey, and Klinklang can benefit from Bouffalant's wallbreaking abilities.

Malamar.comments:
Other Options

An EV spread of 252 HP / 184 SpD / 72 Spe allows Malamar to outspeed Piloswine and Jolly Rhydon, at the cost of no longer avoiding a 3HKO from Jynx and Ninetales. A physically defensive spread with an Impish nature enables Malamar to better take on Sawk, Kangaskhan, and Rapidash, but it makes Malamar worse against special attackers like Rotom and Jynx. Psycho Cut grants Malamar a more reliable way to break down Fighting-types like Throh and Gurdurr, as well as opposing Poison-types like Qwilfish and Silvally-Poison. It also serves as Malamar's best way to damage Alcremie after boosts, but Knock Off offers too much utility to forego except on an offensive set with three attacks + Substitute or Taunt. A Choice Scarf set with Switcheroo over Sleep Talk can cripple checks like Alcremie and Pyukumuku, although this set makes Malamar more passive due to lacking Leftovers and renders it more susceptible to strong attackers like Thwackey and Rapidash.

Checks and Counters

U-turn: Pokemon such as Silvally-Poison can switch into Malamar and force it out with U-turn. More offensive Pokemon like Flapple, Thwackey, and Unfezant can also scare it out, although they are unable to switch in safely and dislike losing their items to Knock Off.

Strong Wallbreakers: While most can't directly switch into it, Malamar's initial bulk and mediocre Speed tier allow dangerous wallbreakers like Kangaskhan, Basculin, Choice Band Morpeko, and Swords Dance Silvally-Poison to heavily damage it.

Fairy-types: Alcremie can either 3HKO Malamar or use it as setup fodder; however, mono-attacking Stored Power variants of Alcremie are unable to beat Malamar. Clefairy can beat it comfortably in a one-on-one, although a +1 Malamar can beat a Clefairy that switches in. Both Fairy-types also dislike losing their items.

Pyukumuku: Unaware ignores Malamar's stat boosts and causes it to deal little damage to Pyukumuku. Pyukumuku can then trap Malamar with Block and proceed to stall it out.

Bulky Ghost-types: Sableye and Gourgeist-XL can stop Malamar from using Superpower and allow themselves to be hit with a weak Knock Off, preventing it from gaining boosts. Spiritomb dislikes losing its item, but it can use its neutrality to Knock Off to turn Malamar into setup fodder or attack it.

sets.name: Contrary Stallbreaker
sets.description:
Malamar serves as a disruptive stallbreaker thanks to its Contrary-boosted Superpower, STAB Knock Off, and decent bulk. Its ability Contrary allows Malamar to take advantage of teams relying on Defog to clear hazards, Intimidate and Parting Shot to deal with physical attackers, and stat drops from moves like Shadow Ball and Grav Apple. Superpower allows Malamar to simultaneously boost and break past walls like Tangela, Stunfisk, and Articuno. Knock Off OHKOes non-Colbur Berry Rotom and weakens switch-ins like Alcremie, Clefairy, and Thwackey. The combination of Rest and Sleep Talk enables Malamar to either continue boosting with Superpower or removing items via Knock Off while also enabling it to outstall foes like Alolan Persian, Cramorant, and Altaria. A specially defensive spread alongside Leftovers lets Malamar avoid the 3HKO from Pokemon such as Ninetales, Cramorant, and Choice Scarf Jynx, although it must be wary of switching into the latter's Trick.

Malamar appreciates entry hazard support from teammates like Qwilfish and Rhydon to wear down threats like Silvally-Poison and Sawk. In return, it can switch into Defoggers like Articuno and Cramorant and deter them while also reliably breaking down common defensive walls like Tangela and Stunfisk. Malamar's teammates appreciate it breaking down, or at least weakening, special attackers such as Ninetales and Skuntank. This enables offensive teammates like Silvally-Poison and Thwackey to clean late-game. As a result of its massive weakness to U-turn, Pokemon such as Rocky Helmet Miltank and Qwilfish, and Flame Body Rapidash are helpful to deter pivots like Thwackey and Silvally formes.

Gourgeist-Small.comments:
Other Options

Gourgeist-S can run a Life Orb set with three attacks and Synthesis, letting it change moves, but the boosts from Choice items are more consistently effective, and Trick lets these sets change moves later. Despite its miserable Special Attack, a Nasty Plot set can make Gourgeist-S deceivingly threatening. It has multiple setup opportunities, decent Speed, Fire Blast for coverage, and longevity with Giga Drain or Synthesis. As fun as this seems, though, its Special Attack is sadly still too low to properly break through common walls like Miltank.

Checks and Counters

Dark-type Pokemon and Coverage: Silvally-Dark, Shiftry, and Alolan Persian can all switch into Poltergeist and KO Gourgeist-S. Although it is bulky, Gourgeist-S's Dark weakness means it can't always freely switch into Knock Off users the likes of Thwackey and Sawk.

Bulky Grass-types: Tangela and other defensive Grass-types like Gourgeist-XL, Shiinotic, and Lurantis can easily take Power Whip. The latter three options all frequently run no item, making them immune to Poltergeist.

Fire-types: While they may fear its strong Poltergeist, Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash are faster than Choice Band Gourgeist-S and can KO any set with a Fire-type attack.

Flying-types: Bulky Flying-types like Altaria, Articuno, and Rotom-S easily switch into Power Whip and can KO Gourgeist-S with their STAB attacks if they avoid getting harmed by Poltergeist. Unfezant boasts an immunity to Poltergeist, making it a great check to Gourgeist-S.

Sap Sipper Normal-types: Sap Sipper Miltank and Bouffalant boast immunities to both of Gourgeist-S's STAB types. They must be wary of Trick, but they still wall it after Trick regardless.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Gourgeist-S is a fantastic revenge killer thanks to its great Speed tier and strong STAB combination. Fast threats like Morpeko, Choice Scarf Rotom, and +1 Speed Silvally formes all get outsped and KOed after some chip damage. It has great utility beyond revenge killing, too. Its physical bulk lets it switch into attacks from Rhydon, and it also boasts a good defensive typing, letting it switch into Choice-locked wallbreakers like Thwackey and Sawk. Trick cripples checks like Miltank and Tangela switching in. This comes at the cost of its revenge killing abilities, though, so be careful to not use Trick too early. The last move is open for a variety of options. Bulky teams generally favor longevity from Synthesis, which lets Gourgeist-S further take advantage of its defensive typing after using Trick. However, more offensive teams will favor Destiny Bond to stop a sweep or Explosion as a one-time nuke.

Its combination of utility and offensive prowess makes Choice Scarf Gourgeist-S a solid option on most team styles, but bulky offense and balance teams benefit the most. However, remember that a team's Knock Off support can actually hurt Gourgeist-S because Poltergeist relies on opposing items. Arguably Gourgeist-S's most synergetic teammate is Miltank, which switches into Ice-type and Fire-type attacks from the likes of Articuno and Rapidash. In return, Gourgeist-S can handle Fighting-type attacks from Pokemon like Sawk, which scare Miltank out. Gourgiest-S fears Knock Off, but walls like Alcremie, Miltank, and Poliwrath can absorb it with little problem. Articuno, Altaria, and Silvally-Poison can weaken or even dismantle opposing Grass-types, letting Gourgeist-S more easily take advantage of Power Whip. Gourgeist-S is also a great fit on offense, as VoltTurn users like Klinklang and the Silvally formes greatly appreciate its ability to switch into and revenge kill threats. In return, those teammates can chip down the opposing team to make revenge killing easier, especially with Spikes support from Qwilfish. On offense, Gourgeist-S's ability to revenge kill fast threats like Alolan Dugtrio and Choice Scarf Sawk gives more room for sweepers like Silvally-Dark, Jynx, and Klinklang to take over the game.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Thanks to its great Speed and powerful STAB attacks, Gourgeist-S can function as a fast wallbreaker with decent utility. With its good bulk and typing, it often gets opportunities to switch into the field and threaten a KO. It's able to take advantage of powerful foes such as Rhydon, Sawk, Thwackey, and Alolan Dugtrio. It also easily handles passive attacks from the likes of Qwilfish and Stunfisk, although it should watch for paralysis. Its strong dual STAB attacks are difficult to switch into, breaking through common walls like Alcremie, Altaria, and Poliwrath. Shadow Sneak makes Gourgeist-S a decent revenge killer, picking off weakened faster threats like Swords Dance Rapidash, Choice Band Froslass, and Choice Scarf Rotom. Trick lets it turn the tides agaisnt defensive switch-ins like Tangela and Sap Sipper Miltank.

Entry hazard support goes a long way to help Gourgeist-S thrive. For example, Stealth Rock gives it a good chance to 2HKO Skuntank. Defensive Stealth Rock setters including Stunfisk and Clefairy help keep hazards up over the course of a game. Offensive Stealth Rock setters like Rhydon and Piloswine particularly help, though, because they can KO the Defog users like Articuno and Altaria that Gourgeist-S can sometimes struggle against. Gourgiest-S is capable at breaking through the defensive Water-types and Ground-types that dominate the tier, giving Pokemon like Rapidash and Klinklang a greater chance of sweeping. With frequent Choice locks but no Synthesis or Speed boost, a good defensive backbone can help preserve Gourgeist-S's longevity. Poliwrath, Miltank, and Throh all provide the necessary type synergy and bulk to give it a Pokemon to fall back on. VoltTurn users like the Silvally formes and Manectric can chip foes and lure in Pokemon that lose to Gourgeist-S, like Poliwrath and Altaria, before pivoting into it. Furthermore, wallbreakers like Jynx, Sawk, and Ninetales take advantage of Gourgeist-S's checks like Tangela, Miltank, and Rapidash.

Shiinotic.comments:
Other Options:

Choice Specs sets can surprise opponents expecting the standard set, and have decent breaking power. However, they lose out on most of what makes Shiinotic effective and are usually outclassed by other options such as Exeggutor and Appletun.

Checks and Counters:

Poison-types: Poison-types like Silvally-Poison, Qwilfish, and Ivysaur are immune to Toxic, resist Moonblast, and threaten to OHKO Shiinotic.

Steel-types: Steel-types are immune to Toxic, resist Shiinotic's STAB moves, and hit it super effectively. Most of them also have other ways to abuse it, like Substitute + Toxic Alolan Dugtrio or Klinklang's Clear Body, which denies Strength Sap.

Ice-types: Ice-types such as Abomasnow and Froslass threaten Shiinotic with their strong, super effective STAB attacks and do not grant much recovery if Strength Sap is used against them. Most of them also have ways to prevent or alleviate the status Shiinotic inflicts.

Super Effective Coverage: Shiinotic needs to be wary of foes running super effective coverage for it, like Iron Head Silvally-Dark, Ice Beam Basculin, and Sludge Bomb Tangela.

Strong Attackers: Some powerful breakers whose STAB moves are not resisted by Shiinotic, like Choice Banded Lycanroc, Choice Specs Exeggutor, and Choice Specs Rotom, can brute-force their way through it.

sets.name: Physical Wall
sets.description:
Shiinotic is a great physical wall due to its unique typing and moveset letting it check a number of threats like Sawk, Thwackey, Malamar, and Appletun. Spore can put switch-ins like Silvally-Poison and Ninetales out of commission, and the move itself forces many switches. The last moveslot can be dedicated to either Toxic, which punishes Pokemon that are immune to Spore like Tangela and Sap Sipper Miltank and puts foes on a timer, or Giga Drain, which makes Shiinotic more reliable at dealing with Ground- and Water-types, such as Rhydon and Basculin. No item is run to avoid Poltergeist from Gourgeist formes and Trevenant; however, Rocky Helmet can be used to punish Pokemon that use contact moves such as Kangaskhan and Silvally-Fighting.

Slower wallbreakers, like Thievul and Swords Dance Rhydon, that are weak to common fast Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Sawk and Thwackey really appreciate Shiinotic's ability to answer them and create opportunities for them to wallbreak with Spore and Effect Spore. Popular Ground-types and Water-types such as Stunfisk and Poliwrath easily fold to threats handled by Shiinotic like Appletun, Morpeko, and Basculin. In return, they answer Poison- and Flying-types like Skuntank and Unfezant and Steel- and Fire-types like Klinklang and Ninetales, respectively, that Shiinotic is weak to. Offensive teammates like Rotom and Jynx as well as defensive options like Rhydon and Hattrem greatly appreciate Shiinotic's ability to absorb Knock Off. Setup sweepers like Ninetales and various Silvally formes also get an immense advantage out of the free turns provided by Spore, and enjoy walls getting crippled by a surprise Toxic.

Pyukumuku.comments:
Other Options

Pyukumuku can sometimes forgo Block to run Rest with both Spite and Toxic. Soak lets Pyukumuku inflict Toxic poison on Steel- and Poison-types Klinklang and Silvally-Poison and helps it better take on Pokemon such as Kangaskhan, Klinklang, and other Silvally formes by making them lose their STAB bonus.

Checks and Counters

Taunt: Pyukumuku is forced to use Struggle if it gets afflicted by Taunt. Taunt users like Skuntank, Alolan Persian, and Qwilfish beat Pyukumuku, but some of them should be wary of being inflicted by Toxic poison on the switch.

Substitute: Substitute users such as Rotom, Klinklang, and Articuno are major threats to Pyukumuku due to them being immune to Block and Toxic; however, PP stalling with Spite and Rest can help against them.

Electric- and Grass-types: Since Pyukumuku is weak to Grass- and Electric-type moves, Pokemon such as Rotom formes, Shiftry, and Flapple are big threats to it.

Strong Wallbreakers: Strong wallbreakers such as Choice Band Sawk and Lycanroc-N 2HKO Pyukumuku.

Stored Power Users: After several Calm Minds, Alcremie, Musharna, Uxie, and Swoobat can overcome Pyukumuku's Unaware with Stored Power. They also have Substitute or Rest to combat Toxic.

sets.name: Unaware Wall
sets.description:
Pyukumuku is the sole viable user of Unaware in ZU, making it a cornerstone on stall teams. Unaware allows Pyukumuku to take on setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Rhydon, non-Stored Power Alcremie, and Silvally formes. Block prevents the foe from switching and allows Pyukumuku to remove them with Toxic or PP stall with Spite. Rest removes status and helps to PP stall foes that cannot 3HKO Pyukumuku, such as Choice Scarf Sawk. Leftovers is normally preferred when entry hazard removal is prevalent on the team, while Heavy-Duty Boots may be used to help against entry hazard stacking matchups.

Pyukumuku's passive nature limits it to fitting exclusively on stall teams. Specially defensive clerics such as Clefairy and Articuno form a good core with Pyukumuku. Physically defensive Pokemon such as Altaria, Tangela, and Golbat, which can take on offensive Grass-types, make for good partners with Pyukumuku. Pokemon that can beat Electric-types such as Rotom-S and block Volt Switch such as Stunfisk are also great partners. If not running Heavy-Duty Boots, or if the item gets removed, Pyukumuku can take big damage from entry hazards and have a harder time checking Silvally-Dark and Rapidash. To avoid this, entry hazard removers such as Altaria and Articuno are essential on stall teams.

Type: Null.comments:
Other Options

A set with Iron Defense / Swords Dance / Crush Claw / Rest and an EV spread of 248 HP / 8 Def / 252 SpD is sometimes used to turn Type: Null into an unbreakable and powerful sweeper. However, this set is not consistent due to it only having Normal-type coverage and is walled by the common Ghost-types in the tier; in addition, it is passive thanks to the lack of Sleep Talk. This set also lacks the utility of the pivot set, and Type: Null also needs multiple boosts to become threatening due to its low Attack stat.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-type Pokemon: Type: Null is weak to Fighting, so it should be careful of Pokemon like Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath.

Strong Physical Wallbreakers: Strong physical wallbreakers such as Sawk and Swords Dance Silvally formes can muscle their way through Type: Null.

Knock Off: Any Pokemon with Knock Off is a threat, as losing Eviolite significantly decreases Type: Null's bulk.

Taunt: Taunt users such as Skuntank and Qwilfish stop Type: Null from recovering and spreading status, forcing it to pivot.
