Setup Sweepers that Bypass Toxic: Setup sweepers with Substitute such as Rotom formes can freely set up in front of Type: Null. Poison- and Steel-types such as Skuntank and Klinklang, as well as Pokemon that can cure status like Spiritomb and Aromatherapy Alcremie, can also set up for free.

Entry Hazards: Although Type: Null is not weak to Stealth Rock, its lack of passive recovery and constant pivoting cause it to get easily chipped down, limiting the amount of times it can switch in and lowering its usefulness as a wall.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
Type: Null acts as a niche defensive pivot in the metagame thanks to its sizable bulk with Eviolite and access to U-turn. This bulk allows it to check top-tier special wallbreakers such as Basculin, Ninetales, and Thievul. Type: Null's slow U-turn allows it to pivot and safely bring in a teammate. Toxic cripples foes and prevents Pokemon such as Rhydon, Rapidash, and Silvally formes from freely setting up in front of it. RestTalk is Type: Null's only form of recovery and lets it consistently pivot. A Sassy nature and 0 Speed IVs minimize Type: Null's Speed, allowing for the slowest U-turns.

Type: Null is a great pick for teams looking for a pivot, special wall, and status absorber condensed into one Pokemon. It pairs well with other pivots, forming a VoltTurn core. Uxie is an excellent pivot to pair with Type: Null, as it benefits from Type: Null's immunity to Ghost and ability to sponge strong special hits; in return, Uxie is able to switch into strong Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr that trouble Type: Null. Wallbreakers such as Thievul, Basculin, and Sawk appreciate Type: Null's slow U-turn safely bringing them in. Although Type: Null can sponge special wallbreakers, it cannot do much damage back and is heavily dependent on pivoting into revenge killers to adequately check special sweepers. Thus, priority users like Kangaskhan and Gurdurr are necessary when dealing with foes such as Alcremie and Ivysaur. Finally, Knock Off absorbers such as Qwilfish and Silvally formes work as partners, as they prevent Type: Null from losing its Eviolite.

Silvally-Dark.comments:
Other Options

X-Scissor is an option over U-turn for a stronger move to threaten opposing Dark-types. Toxic can be used to cripple physical walls such as Tangela and Pyukumuku, but it makes Silvally-Dark less effective at wallbreaking. Defog provides role compression, and it is a niche option on certain teams.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Although they do not appreciate U-turn, Dark-types such as Alolan Persian and Skuntank can take Multi-Attack from Silvally-Dark and threaten it back with status or a powerful hit.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Sawk, Poliwrath, and Gurdurr are able to take Multi-Attack and pressure back with their STAB moves. Gurdurr can also revenge kill Silvally-Dark with Mach Punch, even after it has set up; Choice Scarf Sawk can similarly revenge kill it due to outspeeding it. However, all Fighting-types should be wary of +2 Psychic Fangs.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types such as Alcremie, Clefairy, and Shiinotic can threaten Silvally-Dark with their STAB options, but they have to watch out for Iron Head variants.

Revenge Killers: Faster attackers such as Basculin, Rapidash, and Froslass can outspeed and threaten Silvally-Dark. Pokemon with priority moves such as Kangaskhan and Thwackey can similarly KO it once it has been weakened.

sets.name: Swords Dance Sweeper
sets.description:
Silvally-Dark finds a niche in ZU as a powerful setup sweeper, capable of setting up with Swords Dance and utilizing its Multi-Attack to threaten prominent Pokemon such as Uxie, Spiritomb, and Rotom. However, it faces competition from other Silvally formes. U-turn allows Silvally-Dark to function as an early-game pivot and lets it weaken Dark-types such as Alolan Persian and Skuntank, while Flame Charge allows it to outspeed revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Sawk and Basculin. Psychic Fangs can be used to threaten Fighting-types such as Poliwrath and Sawk, while Iron Head weakens Fairy-types such as Alcremie and Clefairy.

Silvally-Dark fits best on offensive teams as an early-game pivot that can wallbreak with its powerful Multi-Attack. If running Flame Charge, Silvally-Dark should be preserved for late-game, when it can set up with both Swords Dance and Flame Charge and sweep. Silvally-Dark has trouble with Dark-types such as Alolan Persian and Skuntank, so checks to them such as Alcremie and Piloswine, respectively, are appreciated. Checks to Fighting-types such as Rotom-S, Qwilfish, and the aforementioned Alcremie are also appreciated, with Rotom-S forming a VoltTurn core with Silvally-Dark and Qwilfish providing Spikes support, weakening foes such as Qwilfish into the range of +2 Multi-Attack. As Silvally-Dark lacks recovery, entry hazard removal from the likes of Rotom-S and Cramorant is necessary to keep Silvally-Dark healthy to keep pivoting with U-turn. Memento support from Uxie can help Silvally-Dark more easily set up with both Swords Dance and Flame Charge.

Silvally-Fighting.comments:
Other Options

A fully physical Swords Dance set alongside Flame Charge and either Iron Head or Psychic Fangs makes Silvally-Fighting a late-game sweeper. At +2, a healthy Silvally-Fighting can lure in and defeat Alcremie with Iron Head, something other Fighting-types like Sawk cannot do, though this set can't beat defensive Pokemon like Qwilfish, Tangela, and Altaria. This set also faces tough competition from other Silvally formes due to their better offensive or defensive typings.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Alcremie and Clefairy do not take much damage from any of Silvally-Fighting's attacks and can freely set up on it, forcing it to switch.

Bulky Pokemon: Articuno, Eldegoss, Stunfisk, and Uxie don't take much damage from even Silvally-Fighting's super effective coverage attacks. Articuno and Eldegoss can heal damage off with Roost and Regenerator, respectively, though Stunfisk and Uxie lack reliable recovery.

Ghost-types: Spiritomb can switch into any of Silvally-Fighting's attacks with impunity and use it as setup fodder. More offensive Ghost-types, like Rotom and Gourgeist-S, are immune to its STAB move and can revenge kill it with prior damage, though they can't repeatedly switch into Silvally-Fighting's coverage.

Faster Pokemon: With some chip damage, faster Pokemon like Cinccino, Ninetales, and Basculin can revenge kill Silvally-Fighting, though they do not want to directly switch into any of its attacks.

sets.name: BoltBeam Pivot
sets.description:
Silvally-Fighting is an excellent mixed wallbreaker and pivot thanks to its typing and movepool beating common Silvally checks, Defoggers, and entry hazard setters like Rhydon, Altaria, and Qwilfish in one teamslot. U-turn maintains momentum and chips bulkier checks like Alcremie, Eldegoss, and Articuno. Thunderbolt 2HKOes Qwilfish and 3HKOes Poliwrath and Wishiwashi, while Ice Beam targets Tangela, Altaria, and Gourgeist-S. These coverage moves allow Silvally-Fighting to beat common Fighting-type checks that would otherwise switch in safely.

Silvally-Fighting fits well on VoltTurn teams thanks to its good Speed tier, bulk, and coverage against defensive staples like Cramorant, Qwilfish, and Alolan Persian. Fast and slow pivots like Rotom formes, Cinccino, Wishiwashi, and Uxie chip down checks like Articuno, Stunfisk, and Rotom. Silvally-Fighting heavily struggles to break through Fairy-types and generally bulky Pokemon like Eldegoss or Stunfisk without support, so partners that can take these Pokemon on, like Alolan Dugtrio, Perrserker, and Piloswine, can help it pivot more easily. In return, Silvally-Fighting can take on bulky staples weak to its coverage, like Tangela and Poliwrath, which the aforementioned Steel-types struggle against. Checks to Rotom and Gourgeist-S, such as Stunfisk, Eldegoss, and Sap Sipper Miltank, are appreciated. Stunfisk and Miltank can use Toxic to wear down checks to Silvally-Fighting, like Articuno and opposing Stunfisk. Eldegoss and Miltank can provide cleric support to alleviate Silvally-Fighting's vulnerability to residual damage.

Silvally-Flying.comments:
Other Options

Silvally-Flying has no other viable options.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Electric-type Pokemon such as Rotom, Manectric, and Stunfisk resist Multi-Attack and can force Silvally-Flying out with their own STAB attacks. Choice Scarf Manectric is especially notable, outspeeding Silvally-Flying after a Flame Charge.

Rock-types: Rock-type Pokemon such as Rhydon, Coalossal, and Kabutops resist Multi-Attack and can threaten Silvally-Flying back. Rhydon and Coalossal can only check it, however, as they cannot switch into Surf.

Steel-types: Steel-type Pokemon such as Klinklang, and Alolan Dugtrio resist Multi-Attack. Silvally-Flying can break through them with Flame Charge after a Swords Dance boost, though.

Ice-types: Ice-type Pokemon such as Jynx and Articuno can check Silvally-Flying with their super effective STAB attacks. However, Jynx needs a Choice Scarf to be a consistent check. Piloswine, on the other hand, can easily take a hit and retaliate with Icicle Crash or just threaten it with a priority Ice Shard.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Silvally-Flying carves its niche out in ZU as a strong setup sweeper and wallbreaker. Its powerful STAB Multi-Attack especially threatens Pokemon such as Tangela and Throh. Flame Charge enables Silvally-Flying to outspeed revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Rotom, Sawk, and Kabutops. U-turn allows it to retain momentum against Pokemon that handle its attacks like Kabutops. Surf is the coverage move of choice, allowing Silvally-Flying to 2HKO Rhydon and Coalossal.

Silvally-Flying fits well on offense teams as a late-game sweeper, although it can function as a standalone wallbreaker too. Unfezant and Nasty Plot Rotom-S can aid Silvally-Flying by forming an offensive Flying-type spam core, wearing down shared checks and physical walls such as Rhydon, Qwillfish, and Miltank. This core, however, makes the team very weak to Stealth Rock, so it's important to have entry hazard removers such as Kabutops and Rotom. Hattrem is also a great partner, preventing Stealth Rock thanks to Magic Bounce and providing Healing Wish, which is great for offensive teams. Electric-type foes that threaten Silvally-Flying such as Rotom and Manectric can be covered by Stealth Rock setters in Rhydon and Piloswine. Fire-type Pokemon such as Rapidash and Ninetales can help cover the Ice weakness, in addition to Steel-types like Klinklang. Neither covers these weaknesses perfectly, however, due to Alolan Dugtrio and Piloswine threatening them out. A bulky Water-type such as Poliwrath fill in these gaps. Pokemon such as Sawk, Rotom, and Thwackey appreciate wallbreaking from Silvally-Flying opening up a path for a late-game sweep.

Silvally-Poison.comments:
Other Options

Ice Beam is an option over Surf for mixed sets, allowing Silvally-Poison to OHKO Altaria while keeping neutral coverage on the whole tier bar Piloswine when paired with Thunderbolt. However, this leaves Silvally-Poison far less consistent versus Ground- and Rock-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Coalossal. Parting Shot can be used over U-turn on Defog sets, but U-turn's damage is often preferred and Klinklang's Clear Body would prevent Silvally-Poison from freely pivoting. Surf and Thunderbolt are options over U-turn and Flame Charge on Swords Dance Silvally-Poison, giving it better coverage. Grass Pledge is a coverage move hitting Ground-types like Rhydon and Stunfisk while still hitting Water-types like Kabutops and Qwilfish, but it is signficantly weaker than Surf + Thunderbolt.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Even if carrying Surf, Silvally-Poison needs to heavily weaken Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Stunfisk before sweeping.

Rotom: Rotom resists Silvally-Poison's STAB Multi-Attack and can threaten it back with its STAB moves or a burn with Will-O-Wisp. However, sets without Choice Scarf get outspeed by Silvally-Poison and are quickly put in range of a +1 Surf.

Qwilfish: If Silvally-Poison isn't running Thunderbolt, it gets hard walled by Qwilfish, which can cripple it with paralysis and chip it down with Rocky Helmet damage.

Rock-types: If Silvally-Poison doesn't carry Surf, it can't significantly damage Coalossal and risks a Flame Body burn with its contact moves. On the other hand, if it does not have Thunderbolt, it struggles with Kabutops, which can hit it hard.

Mixed Walls: Very bulky Pokemon like Altaria, Miltank, and Uxie can stomach Silvally-Poison's hits and heavily damage it with their repeated attacks, even if Silvally-Poison can break through them after several boosts.

Steel-types: If Silvally-Poison isn't using Flamethrower, it can't really deal damage to Klinklang, and it can significantly weaken Silvally-Poison with its powerful STAB moves.

Faster Attackers: Pokemon like Froslass, Alolan Persian, and Rapidash outspeed Silvally-Poison and can 2HKO it while avoiding an OHKO from it.

sets.name: Work Up
sets.description:
Work Up Silvally-Poison is a powerful mixed attacker thanks to its great bulk and coveted Poison typing, which let it take advantage of common threats like Alcremie and Thwackey. Flamethrower lets Silvally-Poison 2HKO Tangela and OHKO Steel-types like Klinklang after a boost. Thunderbolt is an alternative for massive damage to Qwilfish, Kabutops, and Cramorant, the former resisting every other move Silvally-Poison commonly runs. Surf removes Ground- and Rock-types like Piloswine, Rhydon, and Coalossal after chip damage, as well as beating Rapidash without risking a burn from Flame Body.

Since Silvally-Poison misses a lot of OHKOs after a Work Up, it works better as a mid- or late-game wallbreaker, so it appreciates early-game wallbreakers like Black Belt Sawk and Thwackey weakening walls and removing their items with Knock Off. Rotom formes make for great partners, weakening Ground-types with Will-O-Wisp and their secondary STAB moves so Silvally-Poison can OHKO them later with Surf. Furthermore, most Electric-types like Rotom, Stunfisk, and Manectric can force in Grass-types like Thwackey and Tangela for Silvally-Poison to take advantage of. That said, Tangela can put it to sleep with Sleep Powder on the switch, so Silvally-Poison should be careful setting up versus it. These Electric-types also take care of Steel-types for Silvally-Poison. Defensive pivots like Uxie, Clefairy, and Tangela are appreciated to switch into revenge killers like Froslass and Choice Scarf Sawk or defensive checks like Stunfisk and Miltank, in addition to providing it switch-in opportunities.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Silvally-Poison makes a good pivot with its great bulk and useful set of resistances letting it check attackers like Sawk and Thwackey. It is also one of the few Pokemon packing both a pivoting move and entry hazard removal, bringing great role compression. Surf lets it threaten common hazard setters such as Rhydon, Piloswine, and Coalossal, while Thunderbolt hits Qwilfish, another premier Spikes setter.

Silvally-Poison's key defensive utility, along with its pivoting, makes it a premier choice for VoltTurn teams. As a result, other staples of this archetype like Alolan Persian, Rotom, and Basculin make for great partners to consistently chip the opposing team. Thwackey is a particularly noticeable partner, forcing in Grass-types such as Shiinotic and Tangela, which Silvally-Poison takes advantage of, and providing Grassy Terrain support, negating Silvally-Poison's weakness to Earthquake and providing it passive recovery. Wallbreakers such as Thievul, Arctovish, and Jynx love getting safe switch-in opportunities from pivoting moves, and Silvally-Poison can switch into their checks like Sawk and Thwackey.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Swords Dance Silvally-Poison doubles up as an offensive pivot and late-game cleaner. U-turn allows it to generate momentum and chip its checks like Rhydon and Alolan Persian early-game. Flame Charge lets it outspeed common Choice Scarf users like Sawk and Rotom, and it also provides coverage for Steel-types like Klinklang.

This set fits better on offensive teams due to how immediately threatening it is. It appreciates Pokemon able to take advantage of Rock-, Ground-, and Steel-types such as Thwackey, Basculin, and Sawk, which help it sweep late-game, while they enjoy Silvally-Poison forcing these checks in. Offensive pivots like Rotom, Articuno, and Klinklang make for great partners, forming VoltTurn cores with Silvally-Poison. Thievul is a noticeable partner that can heavily weaken physically bulky foes like Rhydon and Miltank, opening the way for a Silvally-Poison sweep, while in return Silvally-Poison can take advantage of the Fighting- and Fairy-types such as Sawk and Alcremie that Thievul forces in.

Silvally-Psychic.comments:
Other Options

Silvally-Psychic has no other viable options.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Dark-type Pokemon such as Alolan Persian, Morpeko, and Skuntank can all threaten Silvally-Psychic with their STAB attacks while being immune to Multi-Attack. In addition, Alolan Persian deters Swords Dance thanks to Foul Play, making it a very consistent counter.

Ghost-types: Ghost-type Pokemon such as Gourgeist-S and Rotom can revenge kill Silvally-Psychic with their STAB attacks. Choice Scarf Gourgeist-S is especially notable, outspeeding Silvally-Psychic even after a Flame Charge.

Steel-types: Steel-type Pokemon such as Klingklang and Alolan Dugtrio easily take most of Silvally-Psychic’s attacks and hit hard back. However, Silvally-Psychic can break through them with Flame Charge after a Swords Dance boost.

*Physical Walls: Miltank, Rhydon, and Tangela can often trade hits with Silvally-Psychic thanks to their great bulk. However, they are threatened by a boosted Multi-Attack.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Silvally-Psychic acts as a powerful offensive pivot, wallbreaker, and late-game cleaner, threatening common walls such as Qwilfish, Throh, and Poliwrath; however, being vulnerable to Sucker Punch and faster Ghost-types in Choice Scarf Rotom and Gourgeist-S limits its sweeping capabilities. Silvally-Psychic is also often outclassed by better Silvally formes with more desirable types such as Dark and Poison. Flame Charge allows Silvally-Psychic to outspeed Alolan Persian and Choice Scarf users, such as Sawk and Rotom, while also providing coverage for Steel-types such as Klinklang and Alolan Dugtrio. U-turn retains momentum and weakens its checks such as Alolan-Persian, Skuntank, and Uxie. X-Scissor provides coverage for the aforementioned Dark- and Psychic-types and hits harder than U-turn while also not forcing Silvally-Psychic out after it sets up.

Silvally-Psychic fits best on offense teams, where it can break through Fighting-type foes such Gurdurr, Throh, and Poliwrath. Removing them allows Steel- and Normal-types such as Klingklang and Kangaskhan to wreck havoc. Dark-types such as Alolan Persian, Spiritomb, and Skuntank are problematic, so checks to them such as Alcremie and Rhydon are welcomed, as are Dark- and Ghost-type teammates like Skuntank and Gourgeist-S to draw in and chip these threats. Opposing Ghost-types such as Choice Scarf Rotom and Gourgeist-S can revenge kill Silvally-Psychic, so checks to them including Rhydon and Miltank and are appreciated.

Thwackey.comments:
Other Options

Drain Punch is an option on Swords Dance sets, super effectively hitting Steel-types like Klinklang as well as Sap Sipper Bouffalant and Miltank. However, due to its low Base Power and the importance of Knock Off and U-turn for Thwackey's offensive pivot role, it is often not worth using. Terrain Extender is an option if paired with other Grassy Glide users like Flapple, Trevenant, and Gourgeist-S. However, teams built around Grassy Terrain are quite bad due to having few other ways to maximize the Terrain.

Checks and Counters

Poison-types: The likes of Silvally-Poison, Skuntank, and Golbat resist Thwackey's STAB moves and U-turn and can take it out with their super effective STAB moves. However, the last one dislikes losing its Eviolite to Knock Off.

Fire-types: Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales outspeed and OHKO Thwackey with their super effective STAB moves. They also resist Thwackey's STAB moves and U-turn, even if they dislike switching into Knock Off. Due to Rapidash and Coalossal's ability in Flame Body, Thwackey is deterred from coming in and using U-turn, even if Coalossal doesn't resist its STAB moves.

Defensive Grass-types: Bulky Grass-types like Tangela, Shiinotic, and Appletun can take Thwackey's STAB moves. However, U-turn hits them quite hard. Additionally, Tangela dislikes losing its Eviolite to Knock Off, as this jeopardizes its ability to handle other physical attackers like Sawk and Silvally-Dark. Some bulky Grass-types like Gourgeist formes and Shiinotic don't mind U-turn as much but are less common, and Gourgeist-S must watch out for Knock Off instead.

Flying-types: Pokemon such as Articuno, Rotom-S, and Altaria can sponge Thwackey's STAB moves, resist U-turn, and retaliate with their super effective STAB moves, take advantage of it with Defog, or use their own pivoting moves.

Steel-types: Klinklang resists Thwackey's STAB moves and U-turn while sporting decent physical bulk, meaning it can comfortably switch into Thwackey and threaten it with its powerful STAB moves.

Sap Sipper: While quite scarce in the current metagame, Sap Sipper Bouffalant and Miltank are immune to Thwackey's STAB moves, making it very hard for it to clean late-game with Grassy Glide.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Thwackey is a versatile physical attacker, able to wallbreak, clean, and bring utility. Thanks to its Grassy Terrain, Grassy Glide is an amazing priority move that can OHKO faster offensive threats like Froslass and Choice Scarf Rotom, as well as cleaning weakened teams. Grassy Terrain also makes Wood Hammer extremely hard to switch into, 2HKOing defensive behemoths like Uxie and Thick Fat Miltank, as well as common Grass-resistant Pokemon like Skuntank. U-turn lets Thwackey weaken its checks like Skuntank, Appletun, and Rotom-S while keeping momentum. Knock Off removes Thwackey's checks' items, like Eviolite from Tangela and Golbat and Heavy-Duty Boots from Articuno, Altaria, and Rapidash, jeopardizing their ability to come on Thwackey's STAB moves. Additionally, it provides reliable coverage for Gourgeist formes, notably always OHKOing standard Gourgeist-S after Stealth Rock.

This set pairs well in offensive teams with other VoltTurn users, from offensive ones like Morpeko, Rotom, and Silvally-Poison to defensive ones like Uxie, Rotom-S, and Alolan Persian. The resulting cores appreciate entry hazard support to further weaken teams and make up for Grassy Terrain's passive recovery, especially since Thwackey removes Heavy-Duty Boots from common users with Knock Off. Therefore, the likes of Qwilfish and Coalossal make for great partners, also handling some Thwackey checks like Unfezant and appreciating the Earthquake damage reduction from Grassy Terrain. Special wallbreakers like Thievul, Jynx, and Skuntank enjoy Thwackey creating switch-in opportunities with U-turn on the likes of Tangela, Altaria, and Gourgeist formes. Alternatively, Thwackey works well in physical spam teams with the likes of Sawk, Silvally formes, and Kangaskhan, since it can heavily cripple and damage physical behemoths like Tangela, Uxie, and Miltank.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Wielding an Eviolite, Thwackey has the bulk to perform several roles during the game. Swords Dance enables it to clean late-game with its STAB priority Grassy Glide, which is also quite useful mid-game to revenge kill weakened foes like Silvally formes, Sawk, and Rotom. Knock Off and U-turn let Thwackey be an early-game pivot, crippling checks like Tangela, Articuno, and Rapidash and keeping momentum with U-turn. However, the latter can punish Thwackey thanks to Flame Body. U-turn + Swords Dance allows Thwackey to take advantage of Tangela, consistently threatening and weakening them.

Swords Dance Thwackey fits well in balance and bulky offense teams looking for an a secondary revenge killer, late-game cleaner, and check to Rhydon and Rotom. Entry hazard setters including Coalossal, Rhydon, and Qwilfish appreciate the passive recovery from Grassy Terrain and it weakening Earthquake from Kangaskhan and Sawk. In return, they can check some of Thwackey's checks such as Altaria, Rapidash, and Skuntank. Other pivots like Alolan Persian, Rotom, and Silvally formes are also great to form VoltTurn cores with Thwackey, pivoting on each others' checks. Special wallbreakers such as Thievul, Jynx, and Skuntank enjoy Thwackey bringing them safely on the field versus physical walls such as Altaria and Tangela. Other physical wallbreakers such as Swords Dance Silvally formes, especially Poison, appreciate Thwackey removing Tangela's Eviolite, and in return they can weaken physical walls, opening the way for a Thwackey sweep.

Thievul.comments:
Other Options

Thievul can be ran on Electric Terrain teams with Electric Seed, although the archetype isn't very effective. Thievul can use the combination of Throat Spray + Snarl or Sitrus Berry + Substitute to activate Unburden; however, these sets need several turns to set up and are often not worth using. Hyper Beam is Thievul's strongest move and an option on both sets to nuke Dark- and Fairy-types such as Silvally-Dark and Alcremie, but it is exploitable and gives the foe a free turn, and Thievul can outspeed and 2HKO most of these threats with its other moves. A Timid nature can be used on the Choice Specs set to give Thievul a better matchup against more offensive teams; however, a Modest nature lets Thievul break through special walls like Throh, Eviolite-less Clefairy, and Stunfisk with a boost from Stakeout.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Thanks to their great special bulk and resistance to Thievul's STAB moves, Fairy-types such as Carbink, Alcremie, and Clefairy easily wall Thievul, even if non-specially defensive variants of them have to watch out for Stakeout-boosted Psychic.

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Skuntank, Silvally-Dark, and Shiftry tank Dark Pulse and Psychic and threaten Thievul. However, they aren't extremely reliable, as they still take heavy damage from Stakeout-boosted moves and Nasty Plot-boosted Burning Jealousy.

Fighting-types: Without a Stakeout or Nasty Plot boost, Thievul fails to OHKO Fighting-types such as Poliwrath, Gurdurr, and Throh, which can take it out.

Faster Attackers: Due to its mediocre bulk, Choice Specs Thievul is forced out by faster attackers such as Silvally formes, Sawk, and Kangaskhan.

Specially Defensive Walls: Without a Stakeout or Nasty Plot boost, specially defensive walls such as Articuno and Miltank can easily wall Thievul. However, Thievul can 2HKO them with its Stakeout- or Nasty Plot-boosted moves, so they have to be played carefully.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Thievul is a deadly wallbreaker thanks to the combination of Choice Specs and Stakeout. Psychic OHKOes Fighting-types such as Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath with a Stakeout boost and serves as its strongest move for Fairy-types such as Alcremie and Clefairy. Despite its low base power, Burning Jealousy is Thievul's strongest option for Dark-types such as Skuntank, Shiftry, and Alolan Persian. Knock Off is an alternative that cripples Eviolite-reliant walls such as Clefairy and Type: Null, letting Thievul beat them later with its other moves.

Thievul works best on offensive teams looking for a very powerful special wallbreaker. Physical wallbreakers such as Sawk, Rapidash, and Silvally formes can force in physical walls such as Qwilfish, Tangela, and Uxie, giving Thievul an opportunity to switch in. These partners can also break through specially defensive Pokemon that give Thievul a hard time, such as Clefairy, Articuno, and Alcremie. Since Fairy-, Dark-, and Fighting-types such as Clefairy, Silvally-Dark, and Sawk threaten Thievul, checks to these types, such as Rapidash, Gurdurr, and Rotom-S, are appreciated. VoltTurn users such as Thwackey, Uxie, and Rotom-S create opportunities for Thievul to activate Stakeout. Due to Thievul's average Speed tier, it struggles versus more offensive teams; therefore, fast Pokemon such as Froslass and Choice Scarf Sawk make for great partners.

Coalossal.comments:
Other Options

Will-O-Wisp allows Coalossal to consistently cripple opposing physical attackers, but it generally has difficulty fitting the move. Overheat is an alternative over Flamethrower, but its low PP and Special Attack drop make it less desirable than Flamethrower. Heat Crash is also a notable alternative, but Coalossal has trouble breaking Tangela with it. Similarly, Stone Edge can be used over Rock Blast, but its low PP and inaccuracy can be exploited by foes like Articuno.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Coalossal's 4x weakness to Water causes it to be threatened by the plethora of Water-types in ZU, such as Basculin, Qwilfish, and Poliwrath. However, physical Water-types should be wary of being burned by Flame Body.

Ground-type Pokemon and Coverage: Ground-types such as Piloswine, Rhydon, and Galarian Stunfisk are able to exploit Coalossal's 4x weakness to Ground and threaten it with Earthquake, which avoids Flame Body, or set up entry hazards. Physical attackers such as Kangaskhan and Sawk can OHKO Coalossal with Earthquake and not activate Flame Body. Opposing Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash often carry Ground-type coverage moves to threaten Coalossal.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types like Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath can threaten Coalossal with their STAB options, although they dislike being burned.

Knock Off: Coalossal heavily relies on Heavy-Duty Boots to consistently switch in and remove entry hazards. Losing it, combined with its lack of recovery, allows it to get easily worn down.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Coalossal finds a distinct niche in ZU as a Spikes setter that provides good defensive utility against common foes such as Froslass, Articuno, and Rotom. It can force the aforementioned foes out to set up Spikes or remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Stealth Rock can be used if Coalossal is not paired with a Stealth Rock setter or if there is already a Rapid Spin user on the team. Rock Blast allows Coalossal to threaten Substitute users such as Rotom and Articuno and entry hazard removers such as Rotom-S and Altaria. Flamethrower lets Coalossal force out Tangela and Klinklang, giving it the opportunity to reliably use Rapid Spin. Flame Body deters physical attackers like Froslass and Silvally from spamming their STAB moves, and it can potentially cripple threats such as Sawk and physical Basculin in an emergency situation.

Coalossal can provide both entry hazard setting and removal for certain bulky offense teams. As Coalossal has 4x weaknesses to both Water and Ground, it is recommended to pair Coalossal with Grass-types such as Tangela and Thwackey. Tangela is also able to tank hits from Fighting-types such as Sawk and Poliwrath, while Thwackey is able to provide passive recovery and reduce damage from Earthquake. Knock Off absorbers such as Uxie and Alolan Persian can preserve Coalossal's Heavy-Duty Boots, letting it consistently pivot in to remove entry hazards; Uxie can also threaten the aforementioned Fighting-types.

Flapple.comments:
Other Options

An Adamant nature gives Flapple additional breaking power but leaves it outpaced by the likes of Abomasnow and Ivysaur. A Choice Scarf set with a Jolly nature outpaces threats like Alolan Persian and Basculin, but it is still notably outpaced by Accelgor, faster Choice Scarf users like Sawk, and setup sweepers like +1 Silvally formes.

Checks and Counters

Faster Pokemon: While they can't switch-in directly, faster Pokemon like Rotom-S, Accelgor, and Skuntank are able to outspeed and OHKO Flapple due to its poor bulk and defensive typing.

Ice-type Moves: Flapple's 4x weakness to Ice leaves it easily disposed of by faster Ice-types such as Articuno and Cryogonal, while Piloswine is able to OHKO Flapple with its priority Ice Shard. This weakness also leaves it susceptible to Ice-type coverage such as Basculin's Ice Beam.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Klinklang resist both of Flapple's STAB moves.

Fairy-types: While Fairy-types such as Alcremie and Clefairy are unable to switch into Grav Apple, they can take advantage of Flapple if it locks itself into Outrage or Sucker Punch.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Flapple is a devastating wallbreaker thanks to its solid offensive typing in tandem with its Hustle-boosted attacks, allowing it to dismantle defensive cores consisting of Pokemon like Pyukumuku, and Altaria. Grav Apple is Flapple's primary STAB move, with its Defense drop punishing switch-ins, reducing Flapple's reliance on prediction. A mixed Life Orb set with Draco Meteor allows Flapple to bypass Grass-resistant Pokemon and physical walls such as Altaria, Qwilfish, and Tangela. On the the other hand, a Choice Band set with Outrage handles specially bulky Grass-resistant Pokemon like Articuno. Sucker Punch OHKOes faster offensive threats such as Choice Scarf Rotom as well as picking off Accelgor and Alolan Dugtrio after some chip damage. Alternatively, Grassy Glide can be used on Grassy Terrain teams, threatening all faster Pokemon that do not resist Grass. Hustle does allow Flapple to 2HKO just about any Pokemon in the metagame, but its accuracy drop, combined with Flapple relying on a drawback-laden Draco Meteor or Outrage to dispatch Grass-resistant Pokemon such as Altaria, makes Flapple somewhat unreliable.

Flapple's poor bulk and defensive typing give it few direct switch-in opportunities, so it pairs well with bulky pivots that are able to bring it in safely such as Uxie, Alolan Persian, and Rotom-S. Coalossal and Qwilfish provide Flapple entry hazard support as well as pressuring Fairy-types like Alcremie and Clefairy. Special attackers such as Cramorant and Rotom appreciate Flapple's ability to pressure special walls like Appletun and Stunfisk. In return, Cramorant provides entry hazard removal, while Rotom forms an effective VoltTurn core with Flapple. Ninetales and Rapidash easily handle Ice- and Steel-types like Articuno and Klinklang that Flapple struggles with, while Flapple can break down their checks such as Altaria and Cramorant. Late-game cleaners such as Choice Scarf Sawk and Silvally formes appreciate Flapple's ability to break walls such as Qwilfish and Pyukumuku. Flapple works well on Grassy Terrain teams, supporting its teammates by threatening conventional Grass-type checks like Altaria.

Cramorant.comments:
Other Options

Substitute synergizes well with Gulp Missile, helping Cramorant reach the range for its Gorging forme; however, it is generally less effective than Cramorant's other moves. An offensive spread of 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe can be utilized with Hurricane to better offensively pressure foes such as Tangela and Gurdurr.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Electric-types like Rotom and Rotom-S can OHKO Cramorant.

Strong Attackers: Although they dislike taking damage and a potential paralysis from Gulp Missile, strong attackers such as Silvally-Dark and Kangaskhan are capable of easily KOing Cramorant.

Toxic: Toxic from foes like Articuno and Miltank, as residual damage does not activate Gulp Missile.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Cramorant finds a niche in ZU as a Defogger, threatening common entry hazard setters such as Rhydon and Piloswine. Roost is necessary to improve Cramorant's longevity and lets it consistently switch into the likes of Accelgor and Poliwrath. Surf activates Gulp Missile, allowing Cramorant to punish attackers, and can potentially paralyze them if Gulp Missile is activated when it has no more than 50% HP. Hurricane complements Surf by targeting foes such as Qwilifish and Tangela. The given spread allows Cramorant to outspeed Modest Exeggutor and avoid the 2HKO from Nasty Plot boosted Ninetales, as well as checking physical attackers like Sawk and Gurdurr.

Although Cramorant is an effective Defogger, its 4x weakness to Electric makes it susceptible to Rotom formes. Checks to them such as Rhydon and Piloswine are appreciated; Rhydon can also check Kangaskhan. Knock Off absorbers like Silvally formes and Alolan Persian can improve Cramorant's longevity and let it consistently clear entry hazards by keeping Heavy-Duty Boots intact; in return, the latter values it threatening opposing Ground-types. Cramorant's ability to inflict paralysis with Gulp Missile at low HP complements slow wallbreakers like Exeggutor and Skuntank and aids them against fast attackers like Gourgeist-S and Sawk. Powerful attackers such as Silk Scarf Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Sawk appreciate Cramorant's Defog letting them consistently switch into battle.

Hattrem.comments:
Other Options

Hattrem has a very wide movepool with options like Aromatherapy, and Calm Mind. However, getting rid off one of the standard moves comes with a lot of opportunity cost and is not advisable.

Checks and Counters

Item Removal: Hattrem relies on its Eviolite to reliably wall entry hazard setters such as defensive Rhydon and Piloswine and should avoid getting crippled by Knock Off users such as Gurdurr and Sawk.

Offensive Entry Hazard Setters: Foes such as Accelgor and offensive Rhydon easily muscle through Hattrem and can set up entry hazards against it, though Rhydon must be aware of Giga Drain.

Dark-, Ghost-, and Bug-type Pokemon and Coverage: Pokemon such as Shiftry, Rotom, and Accelgor easily defeat Hattrem with their super effective STAB moves.

sets.name: Stall Support
sets.description:
Hattrem is the best user of Magic Bounce in ZU, carving it a niche as a unique form of entry hazard control. Psychic threatens most entry hazard setters, especially Qwilfish. Giga Drain provides coverage for Rhydon and Piloswine while providing some recovery. Rest is Hattrem's best form of recovery and lets it PP stall entry hazard setters it struggles to defeat with its offensive moves, like Galarian Stunfisk. Sleep Talk prevents Hattrem from being completely passive after using Rest. A physically defensive spread is preferred, as most entry hazard setters are physical attackers.

Hattrem fits best on defensive teams that heavily dislike entry hazards. Pokemon that are very susceptible to entry hazards like Alcremie, Cofagrigus, and Golbat enjoy Hattrem consistently keeping entry hazards off the field. A secondary remover such as Articuno, Altaria, or Cramorant is required to handle entry hazard setters like Accelgor and Rhydon, which can break through Hattrem. Solid physical and special walls such as Tangela, Pyukumuku and Stunfisk are needed, as Hattrem tends to invite in wallbreakers such as Silvally formes, Shiftry, and Rotom due to its average bulk and mediocre offensive presence.

Alcremie.comments:
Other Options

Alcremie can run a specially defensive set, making good use of its insane special bulk, access to Aromatherapy, and immunity to Taunt; however, this set is usually outclassed by Clefairy, which has Magic Guard and a superior support movepool. Draining Kiss, while far weaker than Dazzling Gleam, makes Alcremie less reliant on Recover. Flame Orb can be used to avoid Toxic without resorting to Rest or Aromatherapy, but the constant chip damage jeopardizes Alcremie's bulk and limits its setup opportunities.

Checks and Counters

Poison-types: Unless Alcremie is carrying a Psychic move, Poison-types like Poison Jab Qwilfish and Silvally-Poison can take on its attacks and retaliate back with their super effective STAB moves. However, passive ones like defensive Qwilfish lacking Poison Jab and Golbat lacking Toxic are usually unable to beat Alcremie, especially Double Dance sets. Skuntank is noteworthy, as its Psychic immunity allows it to handle every Alcremie variant.

Steel-types: Steel-types like Alolan Dugtrio and Klinklang can take an unboosted Mystical Fire from Alcremie and OHKO back with their super effective STAB moves. They can even break through Acid Armor Alcremie by setting up.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash resist Dazzling Gleam and Mystical Fire. They easily break through Alcremie with their STAB moves or use it as setup fodder.

Physical Wallbreakers: Even with maximum Defense investment, Alcremie is unable to take on powerful physical wallbreakers such as Silvally formes and Thwackey. However, it can easily wall most of them after Acid Armor.

Dark-types: Even though Dark-types such as Silvally-Dark and Shiftry are obliterated by Dazzling Gleam, they completely wall Alcremie's Double Dance set thanks to their immunity to Stored Power. They can take advantage of it to set up.

sets.name: Defensive Calm Mind + Recover
sets.description:
Calm Mind Alcremie serves as a physical wall that is able to check foes like Sawk, Shiftry, and Gurdurr thanks to its typing while doubling as a threatening setup sweeper. Mystical Fire threatens Steel-types like Klinklang and Alolan Dugtrio, which take little damage from Dazzling Gleam. Alternatively, Aromatherapy allows Alcremie to sponge status and break through walls like Toxic Clefairy while also supporting partners that dislike getting statused, such as Miltank, Tangela, and Coalossal. However, without Mystical Fire, Alcremie is unable to beat Steel-types. Aroma Veil provides a Taunt immunity, allowing Alcremie to set up against foes such as Golbat and Qwilfish lacking Poison Jab. Sweet Veil is an option, giving Alcremie an immunity to sleep-inducing moves used by Tangela, Eldegoss, and Jynx.

Alcremie fits well on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate its sweeping potential and defensive utility as a Fairy-type. Ground-types like Piloswine, Rhydon, and Stunfisk threaten Poison-types such as Silvally-Poison and Skuntank. Partners such as Cramorant and Altaria deal with Fire-types such as Rapidash and Ninetales, which can break through Alcremie. Teammates such as Rapidash, Qwilfish, and Manectric, which can check Steel-types, also make for great partners. Strong special wallbreakers such as Poliwrath, Thievul, and Exeggutor can heavily weaken special walls, putting them in range of Alcremie's attacks. This can be very important if Alcremie is not running Aromatherapy to disregard Toxic from threats such as Clefairy and Miltank.

sets.name: Double Dance
sets.description:
Double Dance Alcremie is great against stall and balance teams and has the potential to muscle through most teams once Dark-types have been removed. The combination of Calm Mind and Acid Armor bolsters Alcremie's bulk and Stored Power's base power to incredible levels. Stored Power is preferred for its ability to bypass Unaware Pyukumuku. Rest is used over Recover in order to play around Toxic and other status moves. Leftovers provides passive recovery, which is extremely valuable when Alcremie is asleep for two turns. However, Chesto Berry is an alternative that lets Alcremie fully heal once without drawback.

Because of Alcremie's inability to hit Dark-types, this set appreciates teammates weakening them. Attackers such as Thievul, Gourgeist-Small, and Shiftry can weaken Dark-types, especially with entry hazard support from setters such as Qwilfish, Piloswine, and Stunfisk. Toxic Spikes Qwilfish put Dark-types on a timer, although Skuntank is immune to them and some Dark-types like Morpeko run Heavy-Duty Boots. Fighting-types such as Gurdurr, Poliwrath, and Sawk check Dark- and Steel-types for Alcremie. Leftovers variants of Alcremie value having a sturdy defensive core to counteract its passivity and benefits from partners like Tangela and Altaria. Offensive Steel-types, mainly Alolan Dugtrio and Klinklang, need to be removed before Alcremie can sweep; therefore, teammates such as Rapidash and Sawk are appreciated.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Offensive Alcremie is the best choice for an offensive Fairy-type. Mystical Fire nails Steel-types like Alolan Dugtrio and Klinklang. Psychic destroys Poison-types like Silvally-Poison, Qwilfish, and Golbat, while Calm Mind lets Alcremie break through special walls like Articuno and Clefairy. Heavy-Duty Boots makes it easier for Alcremie to utilize its great defensive typing and switch in against foes like Thievul, Sawk, and Gurdurr, while Life Orb makes Alcremie a better wallbreaker.

Dark-types such as Shiftry, Silvally-Dark, and Morpeko enjoy Alcremie's ability to take on Fighting- and Dark-types such as Gurdurr and Alolan Persian. Physical wallbreakers such as Thwackey and Choice Band Sawk can force in physical walls and pivot, providing Alcremie with wallbreaking opportunities, while also threatening special walls such as Clefairy, which can handle Alcremie. Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine check Fire- and Poison-types such as Rapidash and Silvally-Poison. Partners such as Qwilfish, Rapidash, and Appletun can also wall problematic Fire-types for Alcremie.

Morpeko.comments:
Other Options

Taunt prevents Pokemon such as Uxie and Miltank from setting entry hazards and foes such as Altaria and Rotom-S from recovering health or using Defog. Life Orb grants Morpeko the freedom to switch between its moves, but the recoil can bring it in range of priority moves such as Basculin's Aqua Jet. Also, the decrease in damage output compared to Choice Band leaves Morpeko unable to reliably 2HKO Pokemon such as Altaria.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Bulky Ground-types such as Piloswine, Rhydon, and Stunfisk are able to take most of Morpeko's attacks and force it out. However, they need to be healthy enough to tank a hit from Aura Wheel in Hangry Mode.

Grass-types: Defensive Grass-types such as Tangela and Appletun are able to take a hit from Morpeko and either cripple it with status or force it out.

Physically Defensive Walls: While they are unable to switch into Choice Band Aura Wheel, Morpeko struggles to break through physical walls such as Miltank and Altaria. Other physically bulky Pokemon such physically defensive Alcremie and Gurdurr are able to withstand an attack and OHKO Morpeko.

Revenge Killers: Morpeko is susceptible to revenge killers, especially priority users, due to its poor bulk. Priority users such as Kangaskan, Gurdurr, and Basculin are to pick it off after it is weakened, while certain Choice Scarf users such as Sawk and Silvally are able to revenge kill Morpeko if it lacks a Speed boost.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Morpeko is a unique offensive threat thanks to its signature move Aura Wheel and typing giving it a resistance to common revenge killers like Choice Scarf Rotom and Sucker Punch Shiftry. Aura Wheel gives Morpeko +1 Speed after each use, allowing it to outpace offensive threats like Rapidash and Choice Scarf Sawk to clean weakened teams late-game. Crunch provides Morpeko with a reliable Dark-type STAB move, hitting foes such as Gourgeist formes and Rotom. Seed Bomb is Morpeko's best coverage against opposing Ground-types, granting it a 2HKO against Piloswine and Rhydon after Stealth Rock damage.

Ground-types are able to play around Aura Wheel and must be eliminated before Morpeko can effectively clean. Water-types such Poliwrath, Qwilfish, and Cramorant pair well with Morpeko, as they weaken Ground-types and benefit from Morpeko's ability to pressure Pokemon like Rotom and Articuno. Special attackers like Jynx and Choice Specs Basculin are also able to handle the aforementioned Ground-types and eliminate physically defensive walls such as Acid Armor Alcremie and Tangela. These special attackers also appreciate Morpeko weakening bulky Water-types such as Poliwrath and Pyukumuku.

sets.name: Offensive Utility
sets.description:
Morpeko holds a niche as a Rapid Spin user on offensive teams, handling some common entry hazard setters such as Uxie and Qwilfish. It also threatens Ghost-types such as Rotom, and Gourgeist formes, which other Rapid Spin users such as Coalossal and Kabutops do not do as effectively. However, Morpeko has a poor matchup against other entry hazard setters, especially Ground-types such as Piloswine, Rhydon, and Stunfisk, which limit its effectiveness. Aura Wheel serves as Morpeko's strongest STAB move, hitting foes like Qwilfish, Cramorant, and Articuno in Full Belly Mode and Uxie and Rotom in Hangry Mode. Protect allows Morpeko to safely switch between its Full Belly and Hangry formes while also allowing it to scout moves from Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Sawk. Parting Shot pairs well with the Speed boost provided by Aura Wheel and allows Morpeko to pivot from unfavorable matchups.

Morpeko works best on offensive entry hazard stacking teams that appreciate its Rapid Spin and pivot support. Entry hazard setters such as Qwilfish, Coalossal, and Rhydon synergize well with Morpeko, the former checking Fighting-types such as Sawk and Fairy-types such as Clefairy; in return, Morpeko is able to handle foes like Rotom and Cramorant. Piloswine is able to wear down opposing Ground-types like Rhydon and set Stealth Rock. Wallbreakers like Jynx and Flapple appreciate Morpeko luring walls like Tangela and Altaria and bringing them in with Parting Shot. Attackers such as Kangaskan and setup sweepers such as Silvally-Poison enjoy Morpeko's Rapid Spin support.
